<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations
	(continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Of the $77.6&nbsp;million of cash and cash equivalents as of 2016 year end,
	$59.0&nbsp;million was held outside of the United States.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	maintains
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	funds in its foreign operations to (i)&nbsp;provide adequate working capital;
	(ii)&nbsp;satisfy various regulatory requirements; and/or (iii)&nbsp;take advantage of business expansion opportunities as they arise. The repatriation of cash from certain foreign subsidiaries could have adverse net tax consequences on the company
	should
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	be required to pay and record U.S. income taxes and foreign withholding taxes on such funds. Alternatively, the repatriation of cash from certain other foreign subsidiaries could result in
	favorable net tax consequences for the company.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	periodically evaluates its cash held outside the United States and may pursue opportunities to repatriate certain foreign cash amounts to the extent that
	it does not incur unfavorable net tax consequences.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Trade and other accounts receivable &#150; net of $598.8&nbsp;million as
	of 2016 year end increased $36.3&nbsp;million from 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	levels primarily due to higher sales and an increase in days sales outstanding, and $21.5&nbsp;million of receivables related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant Richmont acquisitions, partially offset by $13.8&nbsp;million of foreign currency translation. Days sales outstanding (trade and other accounts
	receivable &#150; net as of the respective period end, divided by the respective trailing 12 months sales, times 360 days) was 63 days at 2016 year end and 60 days at 2015 year end.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The current portions of net finance and contract receivables of $560.6&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end compared to $529.4&nbsp;million
	at 2015 year end. The long-term portions of net finance and contract receivables of $1,221.2&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end compared to $1,039.3&nbsp;million at 2015 year end. The combined $213.1&nbsp;million increase in net current and long-term
	finance and contract receivables over 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	levels is primarily due to continued growth of the company&#146;s financial services portfolio, partially offset by $15.1&nbsp;million of foreign currency
	translation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Inventories &#150; net of $530.5&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end increased $32.7&nbsp;million from 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	levels primarily due to $21.5&nbsp;million of inventories related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant Richmont acquisitions, as
	well as to support continued higher customer demand and new product introductions, partially offset by $17.8&nbsp;million of foreign currency translation. As of 2016 and 2015 year end, inventory turns (trailing 12 months of cost of goods sold,
	divided by the average of the beginning and ending inventory balance for the trailing 12 months) were 3.3 turns and 3.5 turns, respectively. Inventories accounted for using the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	first-in,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	first-out
</FONT>
	(&#147;FIFO&#148;) method as of 2016 and 2015 year end approximated 59% and 57%, respectively, of total inventories. All other inventories are accounted for using the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	last-in,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	first-out
</FONT>
	(&#147;LIFO&#148;) method. The company&#146;s LIFO reserve was $73.2&nbsp;million and $73.3&nbsp;million as 2016 and 2015 year end, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Notes payable and current maturities of long-term debt of $301.4&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end consisted of
	$150&nbsp;million of the 2017 Notes, $130&nbsp;million of commercial paper borrowings and $21.4&nbsp;million of other notes. Notes payable at 2015 year end totaled $18.4&nbsp;million and there were no commercial paper borrowings outstanding. As of
	2015 year end, the 2017 Notes were included in &#147;Long-term debt&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet as their scheduled maturity was in excess of one year of the 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	balance sheet
	date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Average notes payable outstanding, including commercial paper borrowings, were $49.3&nbsp;million and
	$78.5&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The weighted-average interest rate of 7.09% in 2016 increased from 4.36% last year primarily due to higher interest rates on local borrowings in emerging growth markets (where interest rates are
	generally higher). Average commercial paper borrowings were $26.6&nbsp;million and $52.2&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively, and the weighted-average interest rate of 0.73% in 2016 increased from 0.41% last year. At 2016 year end, the
	weighted-average interest rate on outstanding notes payable of 2.85% compared with 15.82% at 2015 year end. The 2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	rate benefited from lower interest rates on commercial paper borrowings. The 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	rate reflected higher rates on local borrowings in emerging growth markets; no commercial paper was outstanding at 2015 year end.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Accounts payable of $170.9&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end increased $22.6&nbsp;million from 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	levels primarily due to the timing of payments and
	$10.9&nbsp;million of accounts payable related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant Richmont acquisitions, partially offset by $3.8&nbsp;million of foreign currency
	translation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Other accrued liabilities of $307.9&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end increased $11.9&nbsp;million from 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	levels primarily due to a $7.6&nbsp;million increase in derivative liabilities and $6.4&nbsp;million of other accrued liabilities related to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant Richmont acquisitions, partially offset by $8.3&nbsp;million of foreign currency translation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	46
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>

<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

	SNAP-ON INCORPORATED
</B>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Long-term debt of $708.8&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end consisted of (i)
	$250&nbsp;million of the 2018 Notes; (ii) $200&nbsp;million of unsecured 6.70% notes that mature in 2019; (iii) $250&nbsp;million of unsecured 6.125% notes that mature in 2021; and (iv) $8.8&nbsp;million of other long-term debt, including fair value
	adjustments related to interest rate swaps. As of 2016 year end, the 2018 Notes were included in &#147;Long-term debt&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet as their scheduled maturity was in excess of one year of the 2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	balance sheet date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has a
	five-year, $700&nbsp;million multi-currency revolving credit facility that terminates on December&nbsp;15, 2020 (the &#147;Credit Facility&#148;); as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, no amounts were outstanding under the Credit Facility. Borrowings under
	the Credit Facility bear interest at varying rates based on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	then-current, long-term debt ratings. The Credit Facility&#146;s financial covenant requires that
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	maintain, as of each fiscal quarter end, either (i)&nbsp;a ratio not greater than 0.60 to 1.00 of consolidated net debt (consolidated debt net of certain cash adjustments) to the sum of such
	consolidated net debt plus total equity and less accumulated other comprehensive income or loss (the &#147;Debt Ratio&#148;); or (ii)&nbsp;a ratio not greater than 3.50 to 1.00 of such consolidated net debt to earnings before interest, taxes,
	depreciation, amortization and certain other adjustments for the preceding four fiscal quarters then ended (the &#147;Debt to EBITDA Ratio&#148;).
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	may, up to two times during any five-year period
	during the term of the Credit Facility (including any extensions thereof), increase the maximum Debt Ratio to 0.65 to 1.00 and/or increase the maximum Debt to EBITDA Ratio to 3.75 to 1.00 for four consecutive fiscal quarters in connection with
	certain material acquisitions (as defined in the related credit agreement). As of 2016 year end, the company&#146;s actual ratios of 0.24 and 1.02, respectively, were both within the permitted ranges set forth in this financial covenant.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	generally issues commercial paper to fund its financing needs on a short-term basis and uses the Credit Facility as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	back-up
</FONT>
	liquidity to support such commercial paper
	issuances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	Credit Facility and other debt agreements also contain
	certain usual and customary borrowing, affirmative, negative and maintenance covenants. As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	was in compliance with all covenants of its Credit Facility and other debt agreements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes it has sufficient available cash and access to both committed and
	uncommitted credit facilities to cover its expected funding needs on both a short-term and long-term basis.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	manages its aggregate short-term borrowings so as not to exceed its availability under the
	revolving Credit Facility.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes that it can access short-term debt markets, predominantly through commercial paper issuances and existing lines of credit, to fund its short-term requirements and to
	ensure near-term liquidity.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	regularly monitors the credit and financial markets and may take advantage of what it believes are favorable market conditions to issue long-term debt to further improve its
	liquidity and capital resources in 2017. Near-term liquidity requirements for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	include scheduled debt payments (including the repayment of the 2018 Notes; as noted above, the 2017 Notes were repaid on
	January&nbsp;17, 2017), payments of interest and dividends, funding to support new receivables originated by our financial services businesses, capital expenditures, working capital, the funding of pension plans, and funding for share repurchases
	and acquisitions, as they arise.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	intends to make contributions of $7.1&nbsp;million to its foreign pension plans and $2.3&nbsp;million to its domestic pension plans in 2017, as required by law.
	Depending on market and other conditions,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	may make discretionary cash contributions to its pension plans in 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	long-term financing strategy is to maintain continuous access to the debt markets to accommodate its liquidity needs, including the use of commercial
	paper, additional fixed-term debt and/or securitizations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following discussion focuses on information included in the
	accompanying Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Operating Activities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash provided by operating activities of $576.1&nbsp;million in 2016 increased $68.9&nbsp;million from $507.2&nbsp;million in 2015
	primarily due to $69.0&nbsp;million of higher net earnings. Net cash provided by operating activities was $403.1&nbsp;million in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Depreciation expense was $61.4&nbsp;million in 2016, $57.8&nbsp;million in 2015 and $54.8&nbsp;million in 2014. Amortization expense was $24.2&nbsp;million in 2016 and $24.7&nbsp;million in both 2015 and
	2014. See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information on goodwill and other intangible assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

</P>

	&nbsp;

	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations
	(continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Investing Activities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash used by investing activities of $473.4&nbsp;million in 2016 included additions to finance receivables of $915.0&nbsp;million, partially offset by collections of $671.7&nbsp;million. Net cash used
	by investing activities of $306.4&nbsp;million in 2015 included additions to finance receivables of $844.2&nbsp;million, partially offset by collections of $624.8&nbsp;million. Net cash used by investing activities of $273.2&nbsp;million in 2014
	included additions to finance receivables of $746.2&nbsp;million, partially offset by collections of $591.4&nbsp;million. Finance receivables are comprised of extended-term installment payment contracts to both technicians and independent shop
	owners (i.e., franchisees&#146; customers) to enable them to purchase tools and diagnostic and equipment products on an extended-term payment plan, generally with average payment terms approaching four years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash used by investing activities in 2016 also included, on a preliminary basis, a total of $160.4&nbsp;million (net of
	$4.3&nbsp;million of cash acquired) for the acquisitions of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant Richmont. Net cash used by investing activities in 2015 included
	$11.8&nbsp;million for the acquisition of Ecotechnics. Net cash used by investing activities in 2014 included $41.3&nbsp;million for the acquisition of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Pro-Cut.
</FONT>
	See Note 2 to the Consolidated Financial
	Statements for information on acquisitions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Capital expenditures in 2016, 2015 and 2014 totaled $74.3&nbsp;million,
	$80.4&nbsp;million and $80.6&nbsp;million, respectively. Capital expenditures in all three years included continued investments related to the company&#146;s execution of its strategic Value Creation Processes and strategic growth initiatives. The
	company also invested in (i)&nbsp;new product, efficiency, safety and cost reduction initiatives that are intended to expand and improve its manufacturing capabilities worldwide; (ii)&nbsp;new production and machine tooling to enhance manufacturing
	operations, as well as ongoing replacements of manufacturing and distribution equipment, particularly in the United States; (iii)&nbsp;the ongoing replacement and enhancement of the company&#146;s global enterprise resource planning (ERP) management
	information systems; and (iv)&nbsp;improvements in the company&#146;s corporate headquarters and research and development facilities in Kenosha, Wisconsin. Capital expenditures in 2015 also included the purchase of a previously leased manufacturing
	facility in the United Kingdom.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes that its cash generated from operations, as well as its available cash on hand and funds available from its credit facilities will be sufficient to fund the
	company&#146;s capital expenditure requirements in 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Financing Activities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net cash used by financing activities of $116.0&nbsp;million in 2016 included $134.2&nbsp;million of proceeds from a net increase in
	notes payable and other short-term borrowings. Net cash used by financing activities of $236.7&nbsp;million in 2015 included the net repayment of $34.0&nbsp;million of notes payable and other short-term borrowings. Net cash used by financing
	activities of $212.1&nbsp;million in 2014 included the repayment of $100&nbsp;million of unsecured notes at maturity, partially offset by $45.0&nbsp;million of proceeds from a net increase in notes payable and other short-term borrowings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Proceeds from stock purchase and option plan exercises totaled $41.8&nbsp;million in 2016, $41.6&nbsp;million in 2015 and
	$33.0&nbsp;million in 2014.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has undertaken stock repurchases from time to time to offset dilution created by shares issued for employee and franchisee stock purchase plans, stock options and other
	corporate purposes. In 2016,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	repurchased 758,000 shares of its common stock for $120.4&nbsp;million under its previously announced share repurchase programs. As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	had remaining availability to repurchase up to an additional $207.2&nbsp;million in common stock pursuant to its Board of Directors&#146; (the &#147;Board&#148;) authorizations. The purchase of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	common stock is at the company&#146;s discretion, subject to prevailing financial and market conditions.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	repurchased 723,000 shares of its common stock for
	$110.4&nbsp;million in 2015 and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	repurchased 680,000 shares of its common stock for $79.3&nbsp;million in 2014.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes that its cash generated from
	operations, available cash on hand, and funds available from its credit facilities, will be sufficient to fund the company&#146;s share repurchases, if any, in 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has paid consecutive quarterly cash
	dividends, without interruption or reduction, since 1939. Cash dividends paid in 2016, 2015 and 2014 totaled $147.5&nbsp;million, $127.9&nbsp;million and $107.6&nbsp;million, respectively. On November&nbsp;3, 2016, the company announced that its
	Board increased the quarterly cash dividend by 16.4% to $0.71 per share ($2.84 per share annualized). Quarterly dividends in 2016 were $0.71 per share in the fourth quarter and $0.61 per share in the first three quarters ($2.54 per share for the
	year). Quarterly dividends in 2015 were $0.61 per share in the fourth quarter and $0.53 per share in the first three quarters ($2.20 per share for the year). Quarterly dividends in 2014 were $0.53 per share in the fourth quarter and $0.44 per share
	in the first three quarters ($1.85 per share for the year).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes that its cash generated from operations,
	available cash on hand and funds available from its credit facilities will be sufficient to pay dividends in 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Off-Balance-Sheet
</FONT>
	Arrangements
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Except as included below in the section labeled
	&#147;Contractual Obligations and Commitments&#148; and Note 15 to the Consolidated Financial Statements, the company had no
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance-sheet
</FONT>
	arrangements as of 2016 year end.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On January&nbsp;17, 2017,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	repaid the 2017 Notes (included
	in the table above) upon maturity with available cash and cash generated from issuances of commercial paper.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	intends to make contributions of $7.1&nbsp;million to its foreign pension plans and $2.3&nbsp;million to its domestic pension plans in 2017, as required by law.&nbsp;Depending on market and other conditions,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	may make discretionary cash contributions to its pension plans in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	2017.&nbsp;Snap-on
</FONT>
	has not presented estimated pension and postretirement funding contributions
	in the table above as the funding can vary from year to year based on changes in the fair value of the plan assets and actuarial assumptions; see Note 11 and Note 12 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information on&nbsp;the company&#146;s
	benefit&nbsp;plans and payments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Due to the uncertainty of the timing of settlements with taxing authorities,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is unable to make reasonably reliable estimates of the period of cash settlement of unrecognized tax benefits for its remaining uncertain tax liabilities. As a result, $9.4&nbsp;million of unrecognized tax
	benefits have been excluded from the table above;
<I>
</I>
	see Note 8 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information on income taxes.
</FONT>
</P>

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations
	(continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Environmental Matters
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is subject to various federal, state and local government requirements regulating the discharge of materials into the environment or otherwise relating to
	the protection of the environment.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	policy is to comply with these requirements and the company believes that, as a general matter, its policies, practices and procedures are properly designed to
	prevent unreasonable risk of environmental damage, and of resulting financial liability, in connection with its business. Some risk of environmental damage is, however, inherent in some of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	operations and products, as it is with other companies engaged in similar businesses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is and has been engaged in the handling, manufacture, use and disposal of many substances
	classified as hazardous or toxic by one or more regulatory agencies.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes that, as a general matter, its handling, manufacture, use and disposal of these substances are in accordance with
	environmental laws and regulations. It is possible, however, that future knowledge or other developments, such as improved capability to detect substances in the environment or increasingly strict environmental laws and standards and enforcement
	policies, could bring into question the company&#146;s handling, manufacture, use or disposal of these substances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	New Accounting
	Standards
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	See Note 1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information on new accounting standards.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<U>
	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates
</U>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes contain information that is pertinent to management&#146;s discussion and analysis. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with
	accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (&#147;GAAP&#148;) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and
	liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. These estimates are generally based on historical experience, current conditions and on various other assumptions
	that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily available from other sources, as well as identifying and
	assessing our accounting treatment with respect to commitments and contingencies. Actual results could differ from those estimates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In addition to the company&#146;s significant accounting policies described in Note 1 to the Consolidated Financial Statements,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	considers the following
	policies and estimates to be the most critical in understanding the judgments that are involved in the preparation of the company&#146;s consolidated financial statements and the uncertainties that could impact the company&#146;s financial position,
	results of operations and cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Impairment of Goodwill and Other Indefinite-lived Intangible Assets:
</I>
	Goodwill
	and other indefinite-lived intangible assets are tested for impairment annually or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate that the assets might be impaired. Annual impairment tests are performed by the company in the second
	quarter of each year using information available as of fiscal April month end.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	evaluates the recoverability of goodwill by estimating the future discounted cash flows
	of the businesses to which the goodwill relates. Estimated cash flows and related goodwill are grouped at the reporting unit level. The company has determined that its reporting units for testing goodwill impairment are its operating segments or
	components of an operating segment that constitute a business for which discrete financial information is available and for which segment management regularly reviews the operating results. Within its four reportable operating segments, the company
	has identified 11 reporting units.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	evaluates the recoverability of goodwill
	by utilizing an income approach that estimates the fair value of the future discounted cash flows of the reporting units to which the goodwill relates. The future projections, which are based on both past performance and the projections and
	assumptions used in the company&#146;s operating plans, are subject to change as a result of changing economic and competitive conditions. This approach reflects management&#146;s internal outlook at the reporting units, which management believes
	provides the best determination of value due to management&#146;s insight and experience with the reporting units. Significant estimates used by management in the discounted cash flows methodology include estimates of future cash flows based on
	expected growth rates, price increases, working capital levels, expected benefits from RCI initiatives, and a weighted-average cost of capital that reflects the specific risk profile of the reporting unit being tested. The company&#146;s
	methodologies for valuing goodwill are applied consistently on a year-over-year basis; the assumptions used in performing the second quarter 2016 impairment calculations were evaluated in light of then-current market and business conditions.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	continues to believe that the future discounted cash flow valuation model provides the most reasonable and meaningful fair value estimate based upon the reporting units&#146; projections of future operating
	results and cash flows and replicates how market participants would value the company&#146;s reporting units in an orderly transaction.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>

</TD>

</B>
</FONT>

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In the event the fair value of a reporting unit is less than the carrying value,
	including goodwill, the company would then perform an additional assessment that would compare the implied fair value of goodwill with the carrying amount of goodwill. The determination of implied fair value of goodwill would require management to
	compare the estimated fair value of the reporting unit to the estimated fair value of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit; if necessary, the company may consult with valuation specialists to assist with the assessment of the estimated
	fair value of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit. If the implied fair value of the goodwill is less than the carrying value, an impairment loss would be recorded.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	also evaluates the recoverability of its indefinite-lived trademarks by utilizing an
	income approach that estimates the fair value of the future discounted cash flows of each of its trademarks. The future projections, which are based on both past performance and the projections and assumptions used in the company&#146;s operating
	plans, are subject to change as a result of changing economic and competitive conditions. Significant estimates used by management in the discounted cash flows methodology include estimates of future cash flows based on expected growth and royalty
	rates, expected synergies, and a weighted-average cost of capital that reflects the specific risk profile of the trademark being tested. The company&#146;s methodologies for valuing trademarks are applied consistently on a year-over-year basis; the
	assumptions used in performing the second quarter 2016 impairment calculations were evaluated in light of then-current market and business conditions.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	continues to believe that the future discounted
	cash flow valuation model provides the most reasonable and meaningful fair value estimate based upon the trademarks&#146; projected future cash flows and replicates how market participants would value the company&#146;s trademarks in an orderly
	transaction.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Inherent in fair value determinations are significant judgments and estimates, including material assumptions
	about future revenue, profitability and cash flows, the company&#146;s operational plans and its interpretation of current economic indicators. Should the operations of the businesses with which goodwill or other indefinite-lived intangible assets
	are associated incur significant declines in profitability and cash flow due to significant and long-term deterioration in macroeconomic, industry and market conditions, the loss of key customers, changes in technology or markets, significant
	changes in key personnel or litigation, a significant and sustained decrease in share price and/or other events, including effects from the sale or disposal of a reporting unit, some or all of the recorded goodwill or other indefinite-lived
	intangible assets could be subject to impairment and could result in a material adverse effect on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	financial position or results of operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	completed its annual impairment testing of goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible
	assets in the second quarter of 2016, the results of which did not result in any impairment. As of 2016 year end, the company has no accumulated impairment losses. Although the company consistently uses the same methods in developing the assumptions
	and estimates underlying the fair value calculations, such estimates are uncertain by nature and can vary from actual results. In performing its annual impairment testing the company performed a sensitivity analysis on the material assumptions used
	in the discounted cash flow valuation models for each of its 11 reporting units. Based on the company&#146;s second quarter 2016 impairment testing and assuming a hypothetical 10% decrease in the estimated fair values of each of its 11 reporting
	units, the hypothetical fair value of each of the company&#146;s 11 reporting units would have been greater than its carrying value. See Note 6 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further information about goodwill and other intangible
	assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Pension Benefits:
</I>
	The pension benefit obligation and related pension expense are calculated in accordance with
	GAAP and are impacted by certain actuarial assumptions. Changes in these assumptions are primarily influenced by factors outside of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	control, such as changes in economic conditions, and can have
	a significant effect on the amounts reported in the financial statements.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes that the two most critical assumptions are (i)&nbsp;the expected return on plan assets; and (ii)&nbsp;the assumed
	discount rate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans have a long-term investment
	horizon and a total return strategy that emphasizes a capital growth objective. In 2016, the long-term investment performance objective for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic plans&#146; assets was to achieve net of
	expense returns that met or exceeded the 7.6% domestic expected return on plan assets assumption.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	uses a three-year, market-related value asset method of amortizing the difference between actual and
	expected returns on its domestic plans&#146; assets. As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans&#146; assets comprised approximately 86% of the company&#146;s worldwide pension plan assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage52"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations
	(continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Based on forward-looking capital market expectations,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	selected an expected return on plan assets assumption for its U.S. pension plans of 7.5%, a decrease of 10 bps from 2016, to be used in determining pension expense for 2017. In estimating the domestic
	expected return on plan assets,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	utilizes a nominal returns forecasting method. For each asset class, future returns are estimated by identifying the premium of riskier asset classes over lower risk
	alternatives. The methodology constructs expected returns using a &#147;building block&#148; approach to the individual components of total return. These forecasts are stated in both nominal and real (after inflation) terms. This process first
	considers the long-term historical return premium based on the longest set of data available for each asset class. These premiums, calculated using the geometric mean, are then adjusted based on current relative valuation levels, macro-economic
	conditions, and the expected alpha related to active investment management. The asset return assumption is also adjusted by an implicit expense load for estimated administrative and investment-related expenses. Since asset allocation is a key
	determinant of expected investment returns, the current and expected mix of plan assets are also considered when setting the assumption.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Pension expense increases as the expected rate of return on plan assets decreases. Lowering the expected rate of return assumption for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic
	pension plans&#146; assets by 50 bps would have increased
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 domestic pension expense by approximately $4.7&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The objective of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	discount rate assumption is to reflect the rate at which the
	pension benefits could be effectively settled.&nbsp;In making this determination, the company takes into account the timing and amount of benefits that would be available under the plans.&nbsp;The domestic discount rate as of 2016 and 2015 year end
	was selected based on a cash flow matching methodology developed by the company&#146;s outside actuaries and which incorporates a review of current economic conditions. This methodology matches the plans&#146; yearly projected cash flows for
	benefits and service costs to those of hypothetical bond portfolios using high-quality, AA rated or better, corporate bonds from either Moody&#146;s Investors Service or Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s credit rating agencies available at the
	measurement date.&nbsp;This technique calculates bond portfolios that produce adequate cash flows to pay the plans&#146; projected yearly benefits and then selects the portfolio with the highest yield and uses that yield as the recommended discount
	rate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The selection of the 4.5% weighted-average discount rate for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans as of 2016 year end (compared to 4.7% as of 2015 year end) represents the single rate that produces the same present value of cash flows as the estimated benefit plan payments. Lowering
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic discount rate assumption by 50 bps would have increased
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 domestic pension expense and projected benefit obligation by
	approximately $6.7&nbsp;million and $65.3&nbsp;million, respectively. As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic projected benefit obligation comprised approximately 83% of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	worldwide projected benefit obligation.&nbsp;The weighted-average discount rate for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign pension plans of 2.9% (compared to 3.7% as of
	2015 year end) represents the single rate that produces the same present value of cash flows as the estimated benefit plan payments. Lowering
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign discount rate assumption by 50 bps would
	have increased
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 foreign pension expense and projected benefit obligation by approximately $1.7&nbsp;million and $23.4&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Actuarial gains and losses in excess of 10&nbsp;percent of the greater of the projected benefit obligation or market-related value of
	assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over the average remaining service period of active participants or over the average remaining life expectancy for plans with primarily inactive participants. Prior service costs and credits resulting
	from plan amendments are amortized in equal annual amounts over the average remaining service period of active participants or over the average remaining life expectancy for plans with primarily inactive participants.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To determine the 2017 net periodic benefit cost,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is using weighted-average discount rates
	for its domestic and foreign pension plans of 4.5% and 2.9%, respectively, and an expected return on plan assets for its domestic pension plans of 7.5%. The expected returns on plan assets for foreign pension plans ranged from 1.8% and 6.3% as of
	2016 year end. The net change in these two key assumptions from those used in 2016 is expected to increase pension expense in 2017. Other factors, such as changes in plan demographics and discretionary contributions, may further increase or decrease
	pension expense in 2017. See Note 11 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further information on pension plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Allowances for Doubtful Accounts on Finance and Contract Receivables:
</I>
	The
	allowances for doubtful accounts on finance and contract receivables are maintained at levels management believes are adequate to cover probable losses inherent in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	finance and contract
	receivables portfolios as of the measurement date. The allowances represent management&#146;s estimate of the losses inherent in the company&#146;s receivables portfolios based on ongoing assessments and evaluations of collectability and historical
	loss experience. Determination of the proper level of allowances by portfolio requires management to exercise significant judgment about the timing, frequency and severity of losses that could materially affect the provision for doubtful accounts
	and, as a result, net earnings. The allowances take into consideration numerous quantitative and qualitative factors that include receivable type, historical loss experience, loss migration, delinquency trends, collection experience, current
	economic conditions and credit risk characteristics. Some of these factors are influenced by items such as the customers&#146; financial condition, debt-servicing ability, past payment experience, and credit bureau and proprietary Snap-on credit
	model information, as well as the value of the underlying collateral. Changes in economic conditions and assumptions, including the resulting credit quality metrics relative to the performance of the finance and contract receivables portfolios,
	create uncertainty and could result in changes to both the allowances and provisions for doubtful accounts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Management
	utilizes established policies and procedures in an effort to ensure the estimates and assumptions are well controlled, reviewed and consistently applied. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the ratios of the allowances for doubtful accounts to finance and
	contract receivables (the &#147;allowance ratios&#148;) were 3.34% and 1.03%, respectively. As of January&nbsp;2, 2016, the respective allowance ratios were 3.04% and 1.25%. While management believes it exercises prudent judgment and applies
	reasonable assumptions in establishing its estimates for allowances for finance and contract receivables, there can be no assurance that changes in economic conditions or other factors would not adversely impact the financial health of our customers
	and result in changes to the estimates used in the allowance calculations. For reference, a 100 bps increase in the allowance ratios for both finance and contract receivables as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, would have increased
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 provision expense and related allowances for doubtful accounts by approximately $14.6&nbsp;million and $3.8&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For additional information on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	allowances for doubtful accounts, see Note 1 and
	Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<U>
	Outlook
</U>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	expects to make continued progress in 2017 along its defined runways for coherent growth,
	leveraging capabilities already demonstrated in the automotive repair arena and developing and expanding its professional customer base, not only in automotive repair, but in adjacent markets, additional geographies and other areas, including
	extending in critical industries, where the cost and penalties for failure can be high. In pursuit of these initiatives,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	expects that capital expenditures in 2017 will be in a range of $80&nbsp;million
	to $90&nbsp;million.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	also anticipates that its full year 2017 effective income tax rate will be comparable to its 2016 full year rate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_MARKET_RISK>
<A NAME="FIS_MARKET_RISK"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D308837D10K_HTM_TX308837_10">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;7A: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<U>
	Market, Credit and Economic Risks
</U>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Market risk is the potential economic loss that may result from adverse changes in the fair value of financial instruments.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is exposed to market risk from
	changes in interest rates and foreign currency exchange rates, including as a result of the recent weakening of the British pound
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	vis-&agrave;-vis
</FONT>
</FONT>
	the U.S. dollar
	following the United Kingdom&#146;s referendum vote to exit from the European Union.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is also exposed to market risk associated with the stock-based portion of its deferred compensation plans.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	monitors its exposure to these risks and attempts to manage the underlying economic exposures through the use of financial instruments such as foreign currency forward contracts, interest rate swap
	agreements, treasury lock agreements and prepaid equity forward agreements (&#147;equity forwards&#148;).
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	does not use derivative instruments for speculative or trading purposes.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	broad-based business activities help to reduce the impact that volatility in any particular area or related areas may have on its operating earnings as a whole.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	management takes an active role in the risk management process and has developed policies and procedures that require specific administrative and business functions to assist in the
	identification, assessment and control of various risks.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Foreign Currency Risk Management
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has significant international operations and is subject to certain risks inherent with
	foreign operations that include currency fluctuations. Foreign currency exchange risk exists to the extent that
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has payment obligations or receipts denominated in currencies other than the functional
	currency, including intercompany loans denominated in foreign currencies. To manage these exposures,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	identifies naturally offsetting positions and then purchases hedging instruments to protect the
	residual net exposures. See Note 10 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information on foreign currency risk management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Interest
	Rate Risk Management
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	aims to control funding costs by managing the
	exposure created by the differing maturities and interest rate structures of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	borrowings through the use of interest rate swap agreements. Treasury lock agreements are used from time to time to
	manage the potential change in interest rates in anticipation of the possible issuance of fixed rate debt. See Note 10 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for information on interest rate risk management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	utilizes a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Value-at-Risk
</FONT>
</FONT>
	(&#147;VAR&#148;) model to determine the potential
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-day
</FONT>
	loss in the fair value of its interest rate and foreign
	exchange-sensitive financial instruments from adverse changes in market factors. The VAR model estimates were made assuming normal market conditions and a 95% confidence level.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	computations are
	based on the inter-relationships among movements in various currencies and interest rates
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(variance/co-variance
</FONT>
	technique). These inter-relationships were determined by observing interest rate and foreign
	currency market changes over the preceding quarter.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The estimated maximum potential
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-day
</FONT>
	loss in fair value, calculated using the VAR model, as of 2016 and 2015 year end was $0.4&nbsp;million and $0.6&nbsp;million, respectively, on interest rate-sensitive financial instruments, and
	$0.8&nbsp;million and $0.5&nbsp;million, respectively, on foreign currency-sensitive financial instruments. The VAR model is a risk management tool and does not purport to represent actual losses in fair value that will be incurred by
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on,
</FONT>
	nor does it consider the potential effect of favorable changes in market factors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Stock-based
	Deferred Compensation Risk Management
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	aims to manage market risk
	associated with the stock-based portion of its deferred compensation plans through the use of equity forwards. Equity forwards are used to aid in offsetting the potential
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	effect on stock-based deferred compensation from changes in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	stock price. Since stock-based deferred
	compensation liabilities increase as the company&#146;s stock price rises and decrease as the company&#146;s stock price declines, the equity forwards are intended to mitigate the potential impact on deferred compensation expense that may result
	from such
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	changes. See Note 10 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information on stock-based deferred compensation risk management.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD WIDTH="31%">

</B>
</FONT>

	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

	SNAP-ON INCORPORATED
</B>
</FONT>

<A NAME="eolPage55"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Credit Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Credit risk is the possibility of loss from a customer&#146;s failure to make payments according to contract terms. Prior to extending credit, each customer is evaluated, taking into consideration various
	factors, including the customer&#146;s financial condition, debt-servicing ability, past payment experience, credit bureau information, and other financial and qualitative factors that may affect the customer&#146;s ability to repay, as well as the
	value of the underlying collateral. Credit risk is also monitored regularly through the use of internal proprietary custom scoring models to evaluate each transaction at the time of the application for credit and by periodically updating those
	credit scores for ongoing monitoring purposes.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	evaluates credit quality through the use of an internal proprietary measuring system that provides a framework to analyze finance and contract receivables
	on the basis of risk factors of the individual obligor as well as transaction specific risk. The finance and contract receivables are typically monitored through an asset quality review process that closely monitors past due accounts and initiates a
	progressive collection action process when appropriate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Counterparty Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is exposed to credit losses in the event of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performance
</FONT>
	by the counterparties to its various financial agreements, including its foreign currency forward contracts, interest rate swap agreements, treasury lock agreements and prepaid equity forward
	agreements.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	does not obtain collateral or other security to support financial instruments subject to credit risk, but monitors the credit standing of the counterparties and generally enters into
	agreements with financial institution counterparties with a credit rating of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	A-
</FONT>
	or better.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	does not anticipate
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performance
</FONT>
	by its counterparties, but cannot provide assurances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Economic Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Economic risk is the possibility of loss resulting from economic instability in certain areas of the world.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	continually monitors its exposure in these markets; for example, the company will be monitoring the potential effects of the United Kingdom&#146;s referendum vote to exit from the European Union, although it
	is too soon to know what effects the results of the referendum will have on the world economy or the company. Inflation has not had a significant impact on the company.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a result of the above market, credit and economic risks, net earnings and revenues in any particular period may not be representative of full-year results and may vary significantly from year to year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<U>
	Commodity Risk
</U>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is a purchaser of certain commodities such as steel, natural gas and electricity. The company is also a purchaser of&nbsp;components and parts that are
	integrated into the company&#146;s end products,&nbsp;as well as the purchaser of certain finished goods, all of which may contain various commodities including steel, aluminum, nickel, copper and others.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	supply of raw materials and purchased components are generally and readily available from numerous suppliers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The principal raw material used in the manufacture of the company&#146;s products is steel, which the company purchases in competitive, price-sensitive markets. To meet
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	high quality standards, the company&#146;s steel needs range from specialized alloys, which are available only from a limited group of approved suppliers, to commodity types of alloys. These raw
	materials have historically exhibited price and demand cyclicality. Some of these materials have been, and in the future may be, in short supply, particularly in the event of mill shutdowns or production cut backs. As some steel alloys require
	specialized manufacturing procedures,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	could experience inventory shortages if it were required to use an alternative manufacturer on short notice. Additionally, unexpected price increases for raw
	materials could result in higher prices to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	customers or an erosion of the margins on its products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	believes its ability to sell product is also dependent on the number of vehicles on the road, the number of miles driven and the general aging of vehicles.
	These factors affect the frequency, type and amount of service and repair performed on vehicles by technicians, and therefore affect the demand for the number of technicians, the prosperity of the technicians and, consequently, the demand
	technicians have for the company&#146;s tools, other products and services, and the value technicians place on those products and services. The use of other methods of transportation, including more frequent use of public transportation, could
	result in a decrease in the use of privately operated vehicles. A decrease in the use of privately operated vehicles may lead to fewer repairs and less demand for the company&#146;s products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	To the extent that commodity prices increase and the company does not have firm pricing agreements with its suppliers, the company may
	experience margin declines to the extent that it is not able to increase&nbsp;the selling prices of its products.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<EFX_FINANCIAL_STATEMENTS>
<A NAME="FIS_FINANCIAL_STATEMENTS"></A>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D308837D10K_HTM_TX308837_11">
</A>
	Item&nbsp;8: Financial Statements and Supplementary Data
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The financial statements and schedules are listed in Item 15(a) and are incorporated by reference into this Item 8.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_FINANCIAL_STATEMENTS>
<EFX_ACCOUNTING_CHANGES>
<A NAME="FIS_ACCOUNTING_CHANGES"></A>
