<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	New accounting standards
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In March 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued Accounting Standards Update (&#147;ASU&#148;)
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-09,
</FONT>
<I>
	Compensation &#150; Stock Compensation (Topic 718) &#150; Improvements to Employee Share-Based Payment Accounting
</I>
	, which is intended to simplify several aspects of the accounting for
	stock-based compensation transactions, including the income tax consequences, classification of awards as either equity or liabilities, and classification on the statements of cash flows.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	adopted this
	ASU as of January&nbsp;3, 2016. Prior to adoption, excess tax benefits or expense related to stock-based compensation transactions were recognized in &#147;Additional
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	paid-in
</FONT>
	capital&#148; on the accompanying
	Consolidated Balance Sheets; following adoption, all excess tax benefits or expense related to stock-based compensation transactions are recognized prospectively as income tax benefits or expense in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of
	Earnings. In addition, the excess tax benefits or expense from stock-based compensation transactions previously included in &#147;Financing activities&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows are prospectively included on that
	statement as a component of &#147;Net earnings.&#148; To eliminate diversity in practice, the ASU also requires that cash payments to tax authorities in connection with shares withheld to meet employees&#146; statutory tax withholding requirements
	are to be included retrospectively, for all periods presented, in financing activities on the statements of cash flows. The adoption of this ASU did not have a significant impact on the company&#146;s Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2015-17,
</FONT>
<I>
	Balance Sheet Classification of
	Deferred Taxes (Topic 740)
</I>
	, to simplify the presentation of deferred income taxes by requiring that all deferred tax liabilities and assets be classified as long term on the balance sheet.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	adopted
	this ASU as of April&nbsp;2, 2016. Upon adoption,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	retrospectively reclassified $109.9&nbsp;million of current &#147;Deferred income tax assets,&#148; $45.9&nbsp;million of long-term &#147;Deferred
	income tax assets,&#148; and $0.3&nbsp;million of current deferred income tax liabilities (included in &#147;Other accrued liabilities&#148;) to long-term &#147;Deferred income tax liabilities&#148; on the accompanying 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	Consolidated Balance Sheet. Due to the jurisdictional netting of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-current
</FONT>
	deferred tax assets and liabilities,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	overall assets and liabilities were reduced by $155.8&nbsp;million on the revised 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	Consolidated Balance Sheet.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In September 2015, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2015-16,
</FONT>
<I>
	Business Combinations (Topic
	805)
</I>
	, to simplify the accounting and disclosures for entities that report provisional amounts for items in a business combination for which the accounting is incomplete at the end of the reporting period in which the business combination
	occurred. The ASU, which was effective for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	at the beginning of its 2016 fiscal year, requires that an acquirer recognize adjustments to provisional amounts identified during the measurement period in
	the reporting period in which the adjustment amounts are determined as if the accounting had been completed at the acquisition date. Entities are required to present separately on the face of the income statement or disclose in the notes to the
	financial statements the amounts recorded in current-period earnings (by line item) that would have been recorded in previous reporting periods if the adjustments to the provisional amounts had been recognized as of the acquisition date. The
	adoption of this ASU did not have a significant impact on the company&#146;s Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In May 2015,
	the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2015-07,
</FONT>
<I>
	Fair Value Measurement (Topic 820):
</I>
<I>
	Disclosures for Investments in Certain Entities That Calculate Net Asset Value per Share (or Its Equivalent)
</I>
	, which
	removed the requirement to categorize within the fair value hierarchy all investments for which fair value is measured using the net asset value (&#147;NAV&#148;) per share practical expedient. The ASU also removed the requirement to make certain
	disclosures for all investments that are eligible to be measured at fair value using the NAV per share practical expedient. Rather, those disclosures are limited to investments for which the entity has elected to measure the fair value using the
	practical expedient. Entities are required to apply the provisions of this ASU retrospectively to all periods presented.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	adopted ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2015-07
</FONT>
	at the
	beginning of its 2016 fiscal year. In Note 11 and Note 12, certain investments within the company&#146;s pension and postretirement plan assets that are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient have not
	been classified in the fair value hierarchy. The adoption of this ASU did not have a significant impact on the company&#146;s Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In October 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-16,
</FONT>
<I>
	Income Taxes (Topic 740) &#150; Intra-Entity Transfers of Assets Other Than Inventory
</I>
	.&nbsp;The ASU
	eliminates the requirement to defer the recognition of current and deferred income taxes for an intra-entity asset transfer until the asset has been sold to an outside party. Under the new guidance, an entity should recognize the income tax
	consequences of an intra-entity transfer of an asset other than inventory when the transfer occurs. The ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2017, including interim periods within those fiscal years; early adoption is
	permitted as of the beginning of an annual reporting period for which financial statements (interim or annual) have not been issued or made available for issuance (i.e., the first interim period if an entity issues interim financial statements). The
	amendments in this ASU are to be applied on a modified retrospective basis through a cumulative-effect adjustment directly to retained earnings at the time of adoption.&nbsp;The company is currently assessing the impact this ASU will have on its
	consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	72
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	SNAP-ON INCORPORATED
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

<A NAME="eolPage73"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In August 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-15,
</FONT>
<I>
	Statement of Cash Flows (Topic 230)
</I>
	, which adds and/or clarifies guidance on the classification of certain cash receipts and payments in the statement of cash flows. The new guidance
	is intended to reduce diversity in practice in how certain transactions are classified in the statement of cash flows. This ASU is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2017, including interim periods within those fiscal
	years; early adoption is permitted. The company is currently assessing the impact this ASU will have on its consolidated statements of cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-13,
</FONT>
<I>
	Financial Instruments &#150; Credit Losses (Topic 326)
</I>
	, to require the measurement of expected credit
	losses for financial instruments held at the reporting date based on historical experience, current conditions and reasonable forecasts. The main objective of this ASU is to provide financial statement users with more decision-useful information
	about the expected credit losses on financial instruments and other commitments to extend credit held by a reporting entity at each reporting date. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-13
</FONT>
	is effective for fiscal years beginning
	after December&nbsp;15, 2019, including interim periods within those fiscal years; the ASU allows for early adoption as of the beginning of an interim or annual reporting period beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2018. The company is currently
	assessing the impact this ASU will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In May 2014, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2014-09,
</FONT>
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606)
</I>
	, which outlines a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers and
	supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, including industry-specific guidance. Topic 606 is based on the principle that an entity should recognize revenue to depict the transfer of goods or services to customers in an amount that
	reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services. Topic 606 also requires additional disclosure about the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of revenue and cash flows arising from
	customer contracts, including significant judgments and changes in judgments and assets recognized from costs incurred to fulfill a contract.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In December 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-20,
</FONT>
<I>
	Technical Corrections and Improvements to Topic 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers
</I>
	, which
	clarified the guidance in Topic 606 on assessing certain aspects of the new revenue standard, including loan guarantee fees, contract cost impairment testing, provisions for loan losses, disclosure of remaining and prior-period performance
	obligations, contract modifications, contract assets and receivables, refund liabilities, advertising costs and other items. The amendments in this ASU did not change the core principles of the guidance in Topic 606.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In May 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-12,
</FONT>
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers
	(Topic 606) &#150; Narrow-Scope Improvements and Practical Expedients
</I>
	, which clarified the guidance in Topic 606 on assessing collectibility, presentation of sales taxes, noncash consideration, and completed contracts and contract modifications
	at transition. The amendments in this ASU did not change the core principles of the guidance in Topic 606.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In April 2016, the
	FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-10,
</FONT>
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) &#150; Identifying Performance Obligations and Licensing
</I>
	, which clarified the identification of performance
	obligations and the licensing implementation guidance in Topic 606. The amendments in this ASU did not change the core principles of the guidance in Topic 606.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In March 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-08,
</FONT>
<I>
	Revenue from Contracts with Customers (Topic 606) &#150; Principal versus Agent Considerations (Reporting
	Revenue Gross versus Net)
</I>
	. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-08
</FONT>
	clarified the principal-versus-agent implementation guidance in Topic 606 that requires an entity to determine whether the nature of its promise to provide
	goods or services to a customer is performed in a principal or agent capacity and to recognize revenue in a gross or net manner based on its principal/agent designation.&nbsp;The amendments in this ASU did not change the core principles of the
	guidance in Topic 606.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Entities may early adopt Topic 606 only as of annual reporting periods beginning after
	December&nbsp;15, 2016, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period. Entities have the option of adopting this standard using either a full retrospective approach or a modified retrospective approach (i.e., through a
	cumulative-effect adjustment directly to retained earnings at the time of adoption).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>

<TD VALIGN="TOP">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	2016 ANNUAL REPORT
</B>
</FONT>

<A NAME="eolPage74"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	commenced its assessment of Topic 606
	during the second half of 2014 and developed a comprehensive project plan that included representatives from across the company&#146;s business segments. The project plan included analyzing the standard&#146;s impact on the company&#146;s various
	revenue streams, comparing its historical accounting policies and practices to the requirements of the new standard, and identifying potential differences from applying the requirements of the new standard to its contracts. In addition, the company
	is in the process of identifying and implementing appropriate changes to its business processes, systems and controls to support revenue recognition and disclosures under Topic 606.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, and subject to the potential effects of any new related ASUs issued by the FASB in 2017, as well as the
	company&#146;s evaluation of new transactions and contracts, the company has substantially completed its evaluation of the expected impact of adopting Topic 606 and anticipates that the adoption of this standard will not have a significant impact on
	the company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. The company presently expects to adopt Topic 606 at the beginning of its 2018 fiscal year using the modified retrospective approach.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-02,
</FONT>
<I>
	Leases (Topic 842)
</I>
	, to increase
	transparency and comparability among organizations by recognizing lease assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet and disclosing key information about leasing arrangements. The ASU is intended to represent an improvement over previous GAAP,
	which did not require lease assets and lease liabilities to be recognized for most leases. This ASU, which supersedes most current lease guidance, affects any entity that enters into a lease (as that term is defined in the ASU), with some specified
	scope exemptions. ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-02
</FONT>
	is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2018, including interim periods within those fiscal years; the ASU allows for early adoption as of the
	beginning of an interim or annual reporting period. The company is currently assessing the impact this ASU will have on its consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 2: Acquisitions
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On November&nbsp;16, 2016,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	acquired Ryeson Corporation (d/b/a Sturtevant Richmont) for a preliminary cash purchase price of $12.9&nbsp;million (or $12.5&nbsp;million, net of cash acquired). The preliminary purchase price is subject to
	change based upon the finalization of a working capital adjustment that is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2017. Sturtevant Richmont, based in Carol Stream, Illinois, designs, manufactures and distributes mechanical and electronic
	torque wrenches as well as wireless torque error proofing systems for a variety of industrial applications. For segment reporting purposes, the results of operations and assets of Sturtevant Richmont have been included in the Commercial&nbsp;&amp;
	Industrial Group since the acquisition date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, and subject to the finalization of the working
	capital adjustment in the first quarter of 2017, the company has completed the majority of the purchase accounting valuations for the acquired net assets, including the identification of $3.7&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-amortized
</FONT>
	trademarks, of Sturtevant Richmont. On a preliminary basis, the $3.2&nbsp;million excess of the Sturtevant Richmont purchase price over the fair value of the net assets acquired was recorded in
	&#147;Goodwill&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets. The company does not expect any of the goodwill will be deductible for tax purposes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;31, 2016,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	acquired
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	Holding AB
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(&#147;Car-O-Liner&#148;)
</FONT>
</FONT>
	for a preliminary cash purchase price of $151.8&nbsp;million (or $147.9&nbsp;million, net of cash acquired). The preliminary purchase price is
	subject to change based upon the finalization of a working capital adjustment that is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2017.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner,
</FONT>
</FONT>
	headquartered
	in Gothenburg, Sweden, designs and manufactures collision repair equipment, and information and truck alignment systems.&nbsp;For segment reporting purposes, substantially all of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner&#146;s
</FONT>
</FONT>
	results of operations and assets have been included in the Repair Systems&nbsp;&amp; Information Group since the acquisition date, with the remaining
	portions included in the Commercial&nbsp;&amp; Industrial Group.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the purchase accounting
	valuations for the acquired net assets of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner,
</FONT>
</FONT>
	including intangible assets, were not complete. Given the timing and complexity of this acquisition, the
	presentation of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 Consolidated Financial Statements, including the allocation of the purchase
	price, has been prepared on a preliminary basis and changes to the allocations will occur as fair value estimates of the acquired net assets are determined. The company anticipates completing the purchase accounting valuations for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	during the first half of 2017. On a preliminary basis, the $128.1&nbsp;million excess of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	purchase price over the net assets acquired was recorded in &#147;Goodwill&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets. The company does not expect
	any of the goodwill will be deductible for tax purposes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">

	liabilities assumed of

</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>
</TD>

</TD>

</TD>

</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:1.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	3.9&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The post-acquisition revenues and earnings for the Sturtevant Richmont and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	acquisitions, individually and collectively, were neither significant nor material to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 results of
	operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On July&nbsp;27, 2015,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	acquired the assets of Ecotechnics S.p.A.
	(&#147;Ecotechnics&#148;) for a cash purchase price of $11.8&nbsp;million. Ecotechnics designs and manufactures vehicle air conditioning service equipment for original equipment manufacturer (&#147;OEM&#148;) dealerships and the automotive
	aftermarket worldwide.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On May&nbsp;28, 2014,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	acquired substantially all of
	the assets of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Pro-Cut
</FONT>
	International, Inc.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(&#147;Pro-Cut&#148;)
</FONT>
	for a cash purchase price of $41.3&nbsp;million.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Pro-Cut
</FONT>
	designs,
	manufactures and distributes
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-car
</FONT>
	brake lathes, related equipment and accessories used in brake servicing by automotive repair facilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For segment reporting purposes, the results of operations and assets of Ecotechnics and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Pro-Cut
</FONT>
	have been included in the Repair Systems&nbsp;&amp; Information Group since the respective acquisition dates.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Pro forma
	financial information has not been presented for any of these acquisitions as the net effects, individually and collectively, were neither significant nor material to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	results of operations or
	financial position. See Note 6 for further information on goodwill and other intangible assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Trade and Other Accounts Receivable
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	trade and other accounts receivable primarily arise from the sale of tools and
	diagnostic and equipment products to a broad range of industrial and commercial customers and to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	independent franchise van channel on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-extended-term
</FONT>
	basis with payment terms generally ranging from 30 to 120 days.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	trade and other accounts receivable as of 2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Finance and Contract Receivables
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Credit LLC (&#147;SOC&#148;), the company&#146;s financial services operation in the United States, originates extended-term finance and contract
	receivables on sales of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	products sold through the U.S. franchisee and customer network and to certain other customers of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on;
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign finance subsidiaries provide similar financing internationally. Interest income on finance and contract receivables is included in &#147;Financial services revenue&#148; on the accompanying
	Consolidated Statements of Earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	finance receivables are comprised
	of extended-term installment payment contracts to both technicians and independent shop owners (i.e., franchisees&#146; customers) to enable them to purchase tools and diagnostic and equipment products on an extended-term payment plan, generally
	with average payment terms approaching four years. Contract receivables, with payment terms of up to 10 years, are comprised of extended-term installment payment contracts to a broad base of customers worldwide, including shop owners, both
	independents and national chains, for their purchase of tools and diagnostic and equipment products. Contract receivables also include extended-term installment loans to franchisees to meet a number of financing needs, including working capital
	loans, loans to enable new franchisees to fund the purchase of the franchise and van leases. Finance and contract receivables are generally secured by the underlying tools and/or diagnostic or equipment products financed and, for installment loans
	to franchisees, other franchisee assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The components of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	current
	finance and contract receivables as of 2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Delinquency is the primary indicator of credit quality for finance and contract receivables. Receivable
	balances are considered delinquent when contractual payments become 30 days past due.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Finance receivables are generally
	placed on nonaccrual status (nonaccrual of interest and other fees)&nbsp;(i) when a customer is placed on repossession status; (ii)&nbsp;upon receipt of notification of bankruptcy; (iii)&nbsp;upon notification of the death of a customer; or
	(iv)&nbsp;in other instances in which management concludes collectability is not reasonably assured. Finance receivables that are considered nonperforming include receivables that are on nonaccrual status and receivables that are generally more than
	90 days past due.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Contract receivables are generally placed on nonaccrual status (i)&nbsp;when a receivable is more than 90
	days past due or at the point a customer&#146;s account is placed on terminated status regardless of its delinquency status; (ii)&nbsp;upon notification of the death of a customer; or (iii)&nbsp;in other instances in which management concludes
	collectability is not reasonably assured. Contract receivables that are considered nonperforming include receivables that are on nonaccrual status and receivables that are generally more than 90 days past due.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The accrual of interest and other fees is resumed when the finance or contract receivable becomes contractually current and collection of
	all remaining contractual amounts due is reasonably assured. Finance and contract receivables are evaluated for impairment on a collective basis. A receivable is impaired when it is probable that all amounts related to the receivable will not be
	collected according to the contractual terms of the applicable agreement. Impaired finance and contract receivables are covered by the company&#146;s respective allowances for doubtful accounts and are
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	charged-off
</FONT>
	against the allowances when appropriate. As of 2016 and 2015 year end, there were $24.9&nbsp;million and $18.2&nbsp;million, respectively, of impaired finance receivables, and there were
	$2.0&nbsp;million and $1.7&nbsp;million, respectively, of impaired contract receivables.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	It is the general practice of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	financial services business to not engage in contract or loan modifications. In limited instances,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	financial services business may modify certain impaired receivables in troubled debt
	restructurings. The amount and number of restructured finance and contract receivables as of 2016 and 2015 year end were immaterial to both the financial services portfolio and the company&#146;s results of operations and financial position.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a rollforward of the allowances for doubtful accounts for finance and contract
	receivables for 2016 and 2015:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Inventories accounted for using the FIFO method approximated 59% and 57% of total inventories as of 2016
	and 2015 year end, respectively. The company accounts for its
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	inventory on the FIFO method. As of 2016 year end, approximately 33% of the company&#146;s U.S. inventory was accounted for using the FIFO
	method and 67% was accounted for using the LIFO method. There were no LIFO inventory liquidations in 2016, 2015 or 2014.
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Goodwill of $895.5&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end includes, on a preliminary basis, $131.3&nbsp;million
	of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-tax-deductible
</FONT>
</FONT>
	goodwill from the 2016 acquisitions of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant
	Richmont. The preliminary goodwill from
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	of $128.1&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end is distributed as follows: $125.6&nbsp;million in the Repair
	Systems&nbsp;&amp; Information Group and $2.5&nbsp;million in the Commercial&nbsp;&amp; Industrial Group. The preliminary goodwill from Sturtevant Richmont of $3.2&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end is included in the Commercial&nbsp;&amp; Industrial
	Group. The preliminary purchase prices for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	and Sturtevant Richmont acquisitions are subject to the finalization of working capital adjustments that are
	expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2017. See Note 2 for additional information on acquisitions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As the purchase
	accounting valuations for the acquired net assets of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	were not complete as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, the allocation of the purchase price, and resulting
	goodwill, has been prepared on a preliminary basis and changes to the allocations will occur as fair value estimates of the acquired net assets, including intangible assets, are determined.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Additional disclosures related to other intangible assets as of 2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>

	&nbsp;

<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The gross carrying value of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-amortized
</FONT>
	trademarks as of 2016 year end includes $3.7&nbsp;million related to the Sturtevant Richmont acquisition.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Significant and
	unanticipated changes in circumstances, such as declines in profitability and cash flow due to significant and long-term deterioration in macroeconomic, industry and market conditions, the loss of key customers, changes in technology or markets,
	significant changes in key personnel or litigation, a significant and sustained decrease in share price and/or other events, including effects from the sale or disposal of a reporting unit, could require a provision for impairment of goodwill and/or
	other intangible assets in a future period. As of 2016 year end, the company had no accumulated impairment losses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The
	weighted-average amortization periods related to other intangible assets are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	39
</FONT>
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is amortizing its customer relationships on both an
	accelerated and straight-line basis over a 15 year weighted-average life; the remaining intangibles are amortized on a straight-line basis. The weighted-average amortization period for all amortizable intangibles on a combined basis is 11 years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The company&#146;s customer relationships generally have contractual terms of three to five years and are typically renewed
	without significant cost to the company. The weighted-average 15 year life for customer relationships is based on the company&#146;s historical renewal experience. Intangible asset renewal costs are expensed as incurred.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The aggregate amortization expense was $24.2&nbsp;million in 2016 and $24.7&nbsp;million in both 2015 and 2014. Based on current levels
	of amortizable intangible assets and estimated weighted-average useful lives, estimated annual amortization expense is expected to be $23.2&nbsp;million in 2017, $20.8&nbsp;million in 2018, $17.5&nbsp;million in 2019, $13.9&nbsp;million in 2020, and
	$12.2&nbsp;million in 2021.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 7: Exit and Disposal Activities
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	In 2016, the company&#146;s Repair Systems&nbsp;&amp; Information Group recorded $0.9&nbsp;million of severance costs for exit and
	disposal activities, all of which qualified for accrual treatment; no costs for exit and disposal activities were recorded in 2015. In 2014,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	recorded $6.5&nbsp;million of severance costs for exit and
	disposal activities, all of which qualified for accrual treatment. The exit and disposal accrual of $2.8&nbsp;million as of 2016 year end is expected to be fully utilized in 2017.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	anticipates funding
	the remaining cash requirements of its exit and disposal activities with available cash on hand, cash flows from operations and borrowings under the company&#146;s existing credit facilities. The estimated costs for the exit and disposal activities
	were based on management&#146;s best business judgment under prevailing circumstances.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	effective income tax rate on earnings attributable
	to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Incorporated was 31.0% in 2016, 31.7% in 2015, and 32.1% in 2014. The effective tax rate for 2016 included tax benefits from the reversal of deferred tax asset valuation allowances that are now
	expected to be realized in future years, as well as tax benefits associated with the January&nbsp;3, 2016 adoption of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-09;
</FONT>
	these tax benefits were partially offset by tax contingency reserves
	established for certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	tax audits. See Note 1 for further information on the company&#146;s adoption of ASU
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	No.&nbsp;2016-09.
</FONT>
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	A valuation allowance totaling $21.7&nbsp;million, $32.0&nbsp;million and $34.8&nbsp;million as of 2016,
	2015 and 2014 year end, respectively, has been established for deferred income tax assets primarily related to certain subsidiary loss carryforwards that may not be realized. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, the net valuation allowance
	decreased by $10.3&nbsp;million primarily due to a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	subsidiary having, in part, attained three years of cumulative pretax income and, as a result, management concluded there is sufficient positive
	evidence that it is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	more-likely-than-not
</FONT>
	that additional deferred taxes are realizable. Realization of the net deferred income tax assets is dependent on generating sufficient taxable income prior to their
	expiration. Although realization is not assured, management believes it is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	more-likely-than-not
</FONT>
	that the net deferred income tax assets will be realized. The amount of the net deferred income tax assets
	considered realizable, however, could change in the near term if estimates of future taxable income during the carryforward period fluctuate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a reconciliation of the beginning and ending amounts of unrecognized tax benefits for 2016, 2015 and 2014:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<A NAME="eolPage84"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The unrecognized tax benefits of $9.4&nbsp;million, $7.2&nbsp;million and
	$6.4&nbsp;million as of 2016, 2015 and 2014 year end, respectively, would impact the effective income tax rate if recognized. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, unrecognized tax benefits of $3.4&nbsp;million, $2.4&nbsp;million and $3.6&nbsp;million were
	included in &#147;Deferred income tax assets,&#148; &#147;Other accrued liabilities&#148; and &#147;Other long-term liabilities,&#148; respectively, on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet. Interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax
	benefits are recorded in income tax expense. As of 2016, 2015 and 2014 year end, the company had provided for $0.9&nbsp;million, $0.5&nbsp;million and $0.5&nbsp;million, respectively, of accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax
	benefits. During 2016, the company increased the reserve attributable to interest and penalties associated with unrecognized tax benefits by a net $0.4&nbsp;million. As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, $0.4&nbsp;million and $0.5&nbsp;million of accrued
	interest and penalties were included in &#147;Other accrued liabilities&#148; and &#147;Other long-term liabilities,&#148; respectively, on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	and its subsidiaries file income tax returns in the United States and in various state,
	local and foreign jurisdictions. It is reasonably possible that certain unrecognized tax benefits may either be settled with taxing authorities or the statutes of limitations for such items may lapse within the next 12 months, causing
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	gross unrecognized tax benefits to decrease by a range of zero to $4.0&nbsp;million. Over the next 12 months,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	anticipates taking certain tax positions
	on various tax returns for which the related tax benefit does not meet the recognition threshold. Accordingly,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	gross unrecognized tax benefits may increase by a range of zero to
	$1.2&nbsp;million over the next 12 months for uncertain tax positions expected to be taken in future tax filings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	With few
	exceptions,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is no longer subject to U.S. federal and state/local income tax examinations by tax authorities for years prior to 2011, and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is no longer
	subject to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	income tax examinations by tax authorities for years prior to 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The undistributed earnings of all
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	subsidiaries totaled $800.6&nbsp;million,
	$624.1&nbsp;million and $619.1&nbsp;million as of 2016, 2015 and 2014 year end, respectively.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has not provided any deferred taxes on these undistributed earnings as it considers the undistributed
	earnings to be permanently invested. Determination of the amount of unrecognized deferred income tax liability related to these earnings is not practicable.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	SNAP-ON INCORPORATED
</B>

<A NAME="eolPage85"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The annual maturities of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	long-term debt and notes payable over the next five years are $301.4&nbsp;million in 2017 (including $150&nbsp;million of unsecured 5.50% notes due January 2017 (the &#147;2017 Notes&#148;) that were repaid upon maturity), $250&nbsp;million on
	January&nbsp;15, 2018, $200&nbsp;million in 2019, no maturities in 2020, and $250&nbsp;million in 2021. As of 2016 year end, the $250&nbsp;million of 4.25% unsecured notes that mature on January&nbsp;15, 2018, are included in &#147;Long-term
	debt&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet as their scheduled maturity was in excess of one year of the 2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	balance sheet date. See Note 20 regarding the January 2017 repayment of the
	2017 Notes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Average notes payable outstanding, including commercial paper borrowings, were $49.3&nbsp;million and
	$78.5&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively. The weighted-average interest rate of 7.09% in 2016 increased from 4.36% last year primarily due to higher interest rates on local borrowings in emerging growth markets (where interest rates are
	generally higher). Average commercial paper borrowings were $26.6&nbsp;million and $52.2&nbsp;million in 2016 and 2015, respectively, and the weighted-average interest rate of 0.73% in 2016 increased from 0.41% last year. At 2016 year end, the
	weighted-average interest rate on outstanding notes payable of 2.85% compared with 15.82% at 2015 year end. The 2016
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	rate benefited from lower interest rates on commercial paper borrowings. The 2015
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	rate reflected higher rates on local borrowings in emerging growth markets; no commercial paper was outstanding at 2015 year end.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has a five-year, $700&nbsp;million multi-currency revolving credit facility that terminates on December&nbsp;15, 2020 (the &#147;Credit Facility&#148;); as
	of December&nbsp;31, 2016, no amounts were outstanding under the Credit Facility. Borrowings under the Credit Facility bear interest at varying rates based on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	then-current, long-term debt
	ratings. The Credit Facility&#146;s financial covenant requires that
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	maintain, as of each fiscal quarter end, either (i)&nbsp;a ratio not greater than 0.60 to 1.00 of consolidated net debt
	(consolidated debt net of certain cash adjustments) to the sum of such consolidated net debt plus total equity and less accumulated other comprehensive income or loss (the &#147;Debt Ratio&#148;); or (ii)&nbsp;a ratio not greater than 3.50 to 1.00
	of such consolidated net debt to earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization and certain other adjustments for the preceding four fiscal quarters then ended (the &#147;Debt to EBITDA Ratio&#148;).
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	may, up to two times during any five-year period during the term of the Credit Facility (including any extensions thereof), increase the maximum Debt Ratio to 0.65 to 1.00 and/or increase the maximum
	Debt to EBITDA Ratio to 3.75 to 1.00 for four consecutive fiscal quarters in connection with certain material acquisitions (as defined in the related credit agreement). As of 2016 year end, the company&#146;s actual ratios of 0.24 and 1.02,
	respectively, were both within the permitted ranges set forth in this financial covenant.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	generally issues commercial paper to fund its financing needs on a short-term basis and uses the Credit
	Facility as
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	back-up
</FONT>
	liquidity to support such commercial paper issuances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 10: Financial
	Instruments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Derivatives:
</B>
	All derivative instruments are reported in the Consolidated Financial Statements at fair
	value.&nbsp;Changes in the fair value of derivatives are recorded each period in earnings or on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets, depending on whether the derivative is designated and effective as part of a hedged transaction.&nbsp;Gains
	or losses on derivative instruments recorded in Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) (&#147;Accumulated OCI&#148;) must be reclassified to earnings in the period in which earnings are affected by the underlying hedged item and the
	ineffective portion of all hedges must be recognized in earnings in the period that such portion is determined to be ineffective.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The criteria used to determine if hedge accounting treatment is appropriate are (i)&nbsp;the designation of the hedge to an underlying exposure; (ii)&nbsp;whether or not overall risk is being reduced; and
	(iii)&nbsp;if there is a correlation between the value of the derivative instrument and the underlying hedged item. On the date a derivative contract is entered into,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	designates the derivative as a
	fair value hedge, a cash flow hedge, a hedge of a net investment in a foreign operation, or a natural hedging instrument whose change in fair value is recognized as an economic hedge against changes in the value of the hedged item.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	does not use derivative instruments for speculative or trading purposes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The company
	is exposed to global market risks, including the effects of changes in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, and the company&#146;s stock price, and therefore uses derivatives to manage financial exposures that occur in the normal course
	of business. The primary risks managed by using derivative instruments are foreign currency risk, interest rate risk and stock-based deferred compensation risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	2016 ANNUAL REPORT
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">

</FONT>

<A NAME="eolPage86"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Foreign currency risk management:
</B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has significant international operations and is subject to certain risks inherent with foreign operations that include currency fluctuations. Foreign currency exchange risk exists to the extent that
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has payment obligations or receipts denominated in currencies other than the functional currency, including intercompany loans denominated in foreign currencies. To manage these exposures,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	identifies
	naturally offsetting positions and then purchases hedging instruments to protect the residual net
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	exposures.&nbsp;Snap-on
</FONT>
	manages most of these exposures on a consolidated basis, which allows for netting of
	certain exposures to take advantage of natural offsets. Foreign currency forward contracts (&#147;foreign currency forwards&#148;) are used to hedge the net exposures. Gains or losses on net foreign currency hedges are intended to offset losses or
	gains on the underlying net exposures in an effort to reduce the earnings volatility resulting from fluctuating foreign currency exchange rates.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign currency forwards are typically not
	designated as hedges. The fair value changes of these contracts are reported in earnings as foreign exchange gain or loss, which is included in &#147;Other income (expense) &#150; net&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Earnings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	had $144.4&nbsp;million of net foreign currency forward
	buy contracts outstanding comprised of buy contracts including $55.0&nbsp;million in euros, $53.6&nbsp;million in British pounds, $47.0&nbsp;million in Swedish kronor, $9.0&nbsp;million in Hong Kong dollars, $7.0&nbsp;million in South Korean won,
	$5.5&nbsp;million in Singapore dollars, $4.9&nbsp;million in Mexican pesos, $4.6&nbsp;million in Norwegian kroner, and $6.4&nbsp;million in other currencies, and sell contracts comprised of $16.6&nbsp;million in Japanese yen, $11.8&nbsp;million in
	Canadian dollars, $4.4&nbsp;million in Australian dollars, $4.0&nbsp;million in Brazilian real, and $11.8&nbsp;million in other currencies. As of 2015 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	had $98.3&nbsp;million of net foreign
	currency forward buy contracts outstanding comprised of buy contracts including $52.0&nbsp;million in euros, $31.4&nbsp;million in British pounds, $23.4&nbsp;million in Swedish kronor, $12.9&nbsp;million in Singapore dollars, $6.2&nbsp;million in
	South Korean won, $5.5&nbsp;million in Mexican pesos and $8.7&nbsp;million in other currencies, and sell contracts comprised of $18.4&nbsp;million in Canadian dollars, $9.7&nbsp;million in Japanese yen, $4.2&nbsp;million in Australian dollars and
	$9.5&nbsp;million in other currencies.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Interest rate risk management:
</B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	aims to control funding costs by managing the exposure created by the differing maturities and interest rate structures of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	borrowings through the use of interest rate swap agreements
	(&#147;interest rate swaps&#148;) and treasury lock agreements (&#147;treasury locks&#148;).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Interest rate swaps:
</I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	enters into interest rate swaps to manage risks associated with changing interest rates related to the company&#146;s fixed rate borrowings. Interest rate swaps are accounted for as fair value hedges. The
	differentials paid or received on interest rate swaps are recognized as adjustments to &#147;Interest expense&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Earnings.&nbsp;The effective portion of the change in fair value of the derivative is
	recorded in &#147;Long-term debt&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets, while any ineffective portion is recorded as an adjustment to &#147;Interest expense&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Earnings. The notional
	amount of interest rate swaps outstanding and designated as fair value hedges was $100&nbsp;million as of both 2016 and 2015 year end.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Treasury locks:
</I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	entered into a treasury lock in November 2016 to manage the potential change in interest rates in anticipation of the possible
	issuance of fixed rate debt; the treasury lock expires on February&nbsp;28, 2017.&nbsp;Treasury locks are accounted for as cash flow hedges. The effective differentials to be paid or received on treasury locks related to the anticipated issuance of
	fixed rate debt are initially recorded in Accumulated OCI. As of 2016 year end, an unrecognized gain of $8.8&nbsp;million has been recorded in Accumulated OCI on the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheet. Upon the issuance of debt, the related
	amount in Accumulated OCI will be released over the term of the debt and recognized as an adjustment to interest expense on the consolidated statements of earnings. The notional amount of treasury locks outstanding and designated as cash flow hedges
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2016, was $250&nbsp;million; there were no treasury locks outstanding as of January&nbsp;2, 2016, and no treasury locks were settled in 2016 or 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Stock-based deferred compensation risk management:
</B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	aims to manage market risk associated with the stock-based portion of its deferred compensation
	plans through the use of prepaid equity forward agreements (&#147;equity forwards&#148;). Equity forwards are used to aid in offsetting the potential
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	effect on stock-based deferred compensation from changes in
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	stock price. Since stock-based deferred compensation liabilities increase as the company&#146;s stock price rises and decrease as the
	company&#146;s stock price declines, the equity forwards are intended to mitigate the potential impact on deferred compensation expense that may result from such
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	changes. As of 2016 and 2015 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	had equity forwards in place intended to manage market risk with
	respect to 104,400 shares and 107,900 shares, respectively, of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	common stock associated with its deferred compensation plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>

	within the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets as of 2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-LEFT:2.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Treasury locks
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

</EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of 2016 and 2015 year end, the fair value adjustment to long-term debt related to the interest rate
	swaps was $9.8&nbsp;million and $12.9&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Fair value is defined as the price that would be received
	to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between participants at the measurement date. Level&nbsp;2 fair value measurements for derivative assets and liabilities are measured using quoted prices in active markets
	for similar assets and liabilities. Interest rate swaps are valued based on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	six-month
</FONT>
	LIBOR swap rate for similar instruments. Treasury locks are valued based on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	U.S. treasury interest rate. Foreign currency forwards are valued based on exchange rates quoted by domestic and foreign banks for similar instruments. Equity forwards are valued using a market
	approach based primarily on the company&#146;s stock price at the reporting date. The company did not have any derivative assets or liabilities measured at Level&nbsp;1 or Level&nbsp;3, nor did it implement any changes in its valuation techniques as
	of and for its 2016 and 2015 years ended.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The effect of derivative instruments designated as fair value hedges as included in
	the Consolidated Statements of Earnings is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	Accumulated OCI on the Consolidated Balance Sheets and the Consolidated Statements of Earnings is as follows:

<EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<A NAME="FIS_BALANCE_SHEET_3"></A>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="42%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign currency forwards are typically not
	designated as hedges for financial reporting purposes. The fair value changes of foreign currency forwards not designated as hedging instruments are reported in earnings as foreign exchange gain or loss in &#147;Other income (expense) &#150;
	net&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Earnings. In 2016, the $7.4&nbsp;million derivative loss was partially offset by transaction gains on net exposures of $6.1&nbsp;million, resulting in a net foreign exchange loss of
	$1.3&nbsp;million. In 2015, the $15.5&nbsp;million derivative loss was partially offset by transaction gains on net exposures of $12.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a net foreign exchange loss of $2.7&nbsp;million. In 2014, the $19.3&nbsp;million
	derivative loss was partially offset by transaction gains on net exposures of $17.8&nbsp;million, resulting in a net foreign exchange loss of $1.5&nbsp;million. The resulting net foreign exchange losses are included in &#147;Other income (expense)
	&#150; net&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Earnings. See Note 16 for additional information on &#147;Other income (expense) &#150; net.&#148;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	equity forwards are not designated as hedges for financial reporting purposes.&nbsp;Fair value changes of both the equity forwards and related
	stock-based
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(mark-to-market)
</FONT>
</FONT>
	deferred compensation liabilities are reported in &#147;Operating expenses&#148; on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Earnings.
	The $0.8&nbsp;million derivative gain recognized in 2016 was partially offset by $0.3&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	deferred compensation expense. The $4.7&nbsp;million
	derivative gain recognized in 2015 was largely offset by $4.6&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	deferred compensation expense. The $3.6&nbsp;million derivative gain
	recognized in 2014 was offset by $3.6&nbsp;million of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	deferred compensation expense.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of 2016 year end, the maximum maturity date of any fair value hedge was five years.&nbsp;During the next 12 months,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	expects to reclassify into earnings net gains from Accumulated OCI of approximately $0.2&nbsp;million after tax at the time the underlying hedge transactions are realized.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Counterparty risk:
</B>
<I>
</I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is exposed to credit losses in the event of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performance
</FONT>
	by the counterparties to its various financial agreements, including its foreign currency forward contracts, interest rate swap agreements, treasury lock agreements and prepaid equity forward
	agreements.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	does not obtain collateral or other security to support financial instruments subject to credit risk, but monitors the credit standing of the counterparties and generally enters into
	agreements with financial institution counterparties with a credit rating of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	A-
</FONT>
	or better.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	does not anticipate
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-performance
</FONT>
	by its counterparties, but cannot provide assurances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Fair value
	of financial instruments:
</B>
	The fair values of financial instruments that do not approximate the carrying values in the financial statements as of 2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
