<A NAME="eolPage89"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following methods and assumptions were used in estimating the fair value of
	financial instruments:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Finance and contract receivables include both short-term and long-term receivables. The fair value estimates of finance and contract receivables are
	derived utilizing discounted cash flow analyses performed on groupings of receivables that are similar in terms of loan type and characteristics. The cash flow analyses consider recent
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-payment
</FONT>
	trends where
	applicable. The cash flows are discounted over the average life of the receivables using a current market discount rate of a similar term adjusted for credit quality. Significant inputs to the fair value measurements of the receivables are
	unobservable and, as such, are classified as Level&nbsp;3.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Fair value of long-term debt and current maturities of long-term debt was estimated, using Level&nbsp;2 fair value measurements, based on quoted
	market values of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	publicly traded senior debt. The carrying value of long-term debt includes adjustments related to fair value hedges. The fair value of notes payable approximates such
	instruments&#146; carrying value due to their short-term nature.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&#149;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value of all other financial instruments, including trade and other accounts receivable, accounts payable and other financial instruments,
	approximates such instruments&#146; carrying value due to their short-term nature.
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 11: Pension Plans
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has several
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-contributory
</FONT>
	defined benefit pension plans covering most U.S. employees and certain employees in foreign countries.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	also has foreign contributory defined benefit pension plans covering certain foreign employees.
	Retirement benefits are generally provided based on employees&#146; years of service and average earnings or stated amounts for years of service. Normal retirement age is 65, with provisions for earlier retirement.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The status of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	pension plans as of 2016 and 2015 year end is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Amounts in Accumulated OCI that are expected to be amortized as net expense into net
	periodic benefit cost during 2017 are as follows:
</FONT>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The objective of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	discount rate assumption is to
	reflect the rate at which the pension benefits could be effectively settled.&nbsp;In making this determination, the company takes into account the timing and amount of benefits that would be available under the plans.&nbsp;The domestic discount rate
	as of 2016 and 2015 year end was selected based on a cash flow matching methodology developed by the company&#146;s outside actuaries and which incorporates a review of current economic conditions. This methodology matches the plans&#146; yearly
	projected cash flows for benefits and service costs to those of hypothetical bond portfolios using high-quality, AA rated or better, corporate bonds from either Moody&#146;s Investors Service or Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s credit rating agencies
	available at the measurement date. This technique calculates bond portfolios that produce adequate cash flows to pay the plans&#146; projected yearly benefits and then selects the portfolio with the highest yield and uses that yield as the
	recommended discount rate.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The weighted-average discount rate for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans of 4.5% represents the single rate that produces the same present value of cash flows as the estimated benefit plan payments. Lowering
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic discount rate assumption by
	50 basis points (100 basis points (&#147;bps&#148;) equals 1.0 percent) would have increased
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 domestic pension expense and projected benefit obligation by approximately $6.7&nbsp;million and
	$65.3&nbsp;million, respectively. As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic projected benefit obligation comprised approximately 83% of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	worldwide
	projected benefit obligation. The weighted-average discount rate for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign pension plans of 2.9% represents the single rate that produces the same present value of cash flows as the estimated
	benefit plan payments. Lowering
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign discount rate assumption by 50 bps would have increased
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	2016 foreign pension expense and projected
	benefit obligation by approximately $1.7&nbsp;million and $23.4&nbsp;million, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Actuarial gains and losses in
	excess of 10&nbsp;percent of the greater of the projected benefit obligation or market-related value of assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over the average remaining service period of active participants or over the average remaining life
	expectancy for plans with primarily inactive participants. Prior service costs and credits resulting from plan amendments are amortized in equal annual amounts over the average remaining service period of active participants or over the average
	remaining life expectancy for plans with primarily inactive participants.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As a practical expedient,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	uses the calendar year end as the measurement date for its plans.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	funds its pension plans as required by governmental regulation and may consider discretionary
	contributions as conditions warrant.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	intends to make contributions of $7.1&nbsp;million to its foreign pension plans and $2.3&nbsp;million to its domestic pension plans in 2017, as required by law.
	Depending on market and other conditions,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	may make discretionary cash contributions to its pension plans in 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

</FONT>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>
</TD>

</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans have a long-term investment
	horizon and a total return strategy that emphasizes a capital growth objective. The long-term investment performance objective for
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic plans&#146; assets is to achieve net of expense
	returns that meet or exceed the 7.5% domestic long-term return on plan assets assumption used for reporting purposes.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	uses a three-year, market-related value asset method of amortizing the difference
	between actual and expected returns on its domestic plans&#146; assets. As of 2016 year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans&#146; assets comprised approximately 86% of the company&#146;s worldwide
	pension plan assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The basis for determining the overall expected long-term return on plan assets assumption is a nominal
	returns forecasting method. For each asset class, future returns are estimated by identifying the premium of riskier asset classes over lower risk alternatives. The methodology constructs expected returns using a &#147;building block&#148; approach
	to the individual components of total return. These forecasts are stated in both nominal and real (after inflation) terms. This process first considers the long-term historical return premium based on the longest set of data available for each asset
	class. These premiums, which are calculated using the geometric mean, are then adjusted based on current relative valuation levels, macro-economic conditions, and the expected alpha related to active investment management. The asset return
	assumption is also adjusted by an implicit expense load for estimated administrative and investment-related expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For
	risk and correlation assumptions, the actual experience for each asset class is reviewed for the longest time period available. Expected relationships for a 10 to 20 year time horizon are determined based upon historical results, with adjustments
	made for material changes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Investments are diversified to attempt to minimize the risk of large losses. Since asset
	allocation is a key determinant of expected investment returns, assets are periodically rebalanced to the targeted allocation to correct significant deviations from the asset allocation policy that are caused by market fluctuations and cash flow.
	Asset/liability studies are conducted periodically to determine if any revisions to the strategic asset allocation policy are necessary.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans&#146; target allocation and actual weighted-average asset allocation by asset category and fair value of plan assets as of
	2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value measurement hierarchy prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value. The hierarchy
	gives the highest priority (&#147;Level&nbsp;1&#148;) to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets and liabilities and the lowest priority (&#147;Level&nbsp;3&#148;) to unobservable inputs. Fair value measurements primarily
	based on observable market information are given a &#147;Level&nbsp;2&#148; priority.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	92
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	SNAP-ON INCORPORATED
</B>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;

<A NAME="eolPage93"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Certain equity and debt securities are valued at quoted per share or unit market prices
	for which an official close or last trade pricing on an active exchange is available and are categorized as Level&nbsp;1 in the fair value hierarchy.&nbsp;If quoted market prices are not readily available for specific securities, values are
	estimated using quoted prices of securities with similar characteristics and are categorized as Level&nbsp;2 in the fair value hierarchy. Insurance contracts are valued at the present value of the estimated future cash flows promised under the terms
	of the insurance contracts and are categorized as Level&nbsp;2 in the fair value hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Commingled equity securities and
	commingled multi-strategy funds are valued at the NAV per share or unit multiplied by the number of shares or units held as of the measurement date, as reported by the fund managers. The share or unit price is quoted on a private market and is based
	on the value of the underlying investments, which are primarily based on observable inputs; such investments that are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient have not been classified in the fair value
	hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Private equity partnership funds, hedge funds, and real estate and other real assets are valued at the NAV as
	reported by the fund managers. Private equity partnership funds, certain hedge funds, and certain real estate and other real assets are valued based on the proportionate interest or share of net assets held by the pension plan, which is based on the
	estimated fair market value of the underlying investments. Certain other hedge funds and real estate and other real assets are valued at the NAV per share or unit multiplied by the number of shares or units held as of the measurement date, based on
	the estimated value of the underlying investments as reported by the fund managers. These investments are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient and have not been classified in the fair value
	hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The company regularly reviews fund performance directly with its investment advisor and the fund managers, and
	performs qualitative analysis to corroborate the reasonableness of the reported NAVs. For funds for which the company did not receive a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	NAV, the company recorded an estimate of the change in fair
	value for the latest period based on return estimates and other fund activity obtained from the fund managers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The columns
	labeled &#147;Investments Measured at NAV&#148; in the following tables reflect certain investments that are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient and have not been categorized in the fair value
	hierarchy. The fair value amounts presented in these tables are intended to permit a reconciliation of the fair value hierarchy to the pension plan assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a summary, by asset category, of the fair value and the level within the fair value hierarchy of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	domestic pension plans&#146; assets
	as of 2016 year end:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	primary investment objective for its foreign
	pension plans&#146; assets is to meet the projected obligations to the beneficiaries over a long period of time, and to do so in a manner that is consistent with the company&#146;s risk tolerance. The foreign asset allocation policies consider the
	company&#146;s financial strength and long-term asset class risk/return expectations, since the obligations are long term in nature. The company believes the foreign pension plans&#146; assets, which are managed locally by professional investment
	firms, are well diversified.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The expected long-term rates of return on foreign plans&#146; assets, which ranged from 1.8% to
	6.3% as of 2016 year end, reflect management&#146;s expectations of long-term average rates of return on funds invested to provide benefits included in the plans&#146; projected benefit obligation. The expected returns are based on outlooks for
	inflation, fixed income returns and equity returns, asset allocations and investment strategies. Differences between actual and expected returns on foreign pension plans&#146; assets are recorded as an actuarial gain or loss and amortized
	accordingly.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	foreign pension plans&#146; target allocation and actual
	weighted-average asset allocation by asset category and fair value of plan assets as of 2016 and 2015 year end are as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has several 401(k) plans covering certain U.S. employees.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	employer match to the 401(k) plans is made with cash contributions. For 2016, 2015 and 2014,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	recognized $8.2&nbsp;million, $7.0&nbsp;million and
	$6.5&nbsp;million, respectively, of expense related to its 401(k) plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 12: Postretirement Plans
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	provides health care benefits for certain retired U.S. employees. Employees retiring
	prior to 1989 were eligible for retiree medical coverage upon reaching early retirement age, with no retiree contributions required. Benefits are paid based on deductibles and percentages of covered expenses and take into consideration payments made
	by Medicare and other insurance coverage.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Since 1989, U.S. retirees have been eligible for comprehensive major medical plans.
	Benefits are paid based on deductibles and percentages of covered expenses, and plan provisions allow for benefit and coverage changes. Most retirees are required to pay the entire cost of the coverage, but
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	may elect to subsidize the cost of coverage under certain circumstances.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has a Voluntary Employees Beneficiary Association (&#147;VEBA&#148;) trust for the funding of existing postretirement health care benefits for certain
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-salaried
</FONT>
	retirees in the United States; all other retiree health care plans are unfunded.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

	of prior unrecognized gains, included in Accumulated OCI on the accompanying 2016 Consolidated Balance Sheet, in net periodic benefit cost during 2017.

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The methodology for selecting the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	2016 and 2015
	weighted-average discount rate for the company&#146;s domestic postretirement plans was to match the plans&#146; yearly projected cash flows for benefits and service costs to those of hypothetical bond portfolios using high-quality, AA rated or
	better, corporate bonds from either Moody&#146;s Investors Service or Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s credit rating agencies available at the measurement date.&nbsp;As a practical expedient,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	uses the
	calendar year end as the measurement date for its plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	For 2017, the actuarial calculations assume a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-65
</FONT>
	health care cost trend rate of 5.9% and a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	post-65
</FONT>
	health care cost trend rate of 6.6%, both decreasing gradually to 4.5% in 2038 and thereafter. As of 2016 year end, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-percentage-point
</FONT>
	increase in the health care cost trend rate for future years would increase the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation by approximately $0.6&nbsp;million and the aggregate of the service
	cost and interest cost components by less than $0.1&nbsp;million. Conversely, a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-percentage-point
</FONT>
	decrease in the health care cost trend rate for future years would decrease the accumulated postretirement
	benefit obligation by $0.6&nbsp;million and the aggregate of the service cost and interest rate components by less than $0.1&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following benefit payments, which reflect expected future service, are expected to be paid as follows:
</FONT>
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The objective of the VEBA trust is to achieve net of expense returns that meet or exceed the 6.6%
	long-term return on plan assets assumption used for reporting purposes. Investments are diversified to attempt to minimize the risk of large losses. Since asset allocation is a key determinant of expected investment returns, assets are periodically
	rebalanced to the targeted allocation to correct significant deviations from the asset allocation policy that are caused by market fluctuations and cash flow.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The basis for determining the overall expected long-term return on plan assets assumption is a nominal returns forecasting method. For each asset class, future returns are estimated by identifying the
	premium of riskier asset classes over lower risk alternatives. The methodology constructs expected returns using a &#147;building block&#148; approach to the individual components of total return. These forecasts are stated in both nominal and real
	(after inflation) terms. This process first considers the long-term historical return premium based on the longest set of data available for each asset class. These premiums, which are calculated using the geometric mean, are then adjusted based on
	current relative valuation levels and macro-economic conditions. The asset return assumption is also adjusted by an implicit expense load for estimated administrative and investment-related expenses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<B>
	2016 ANNUAL REPORT
</B>
</FONT>

<FONT SIZE="1">

<A NAME="eolPage98"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value measurement hierarchy prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value. The hierarchy
	gives the highest priority (Level 1) to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets and liabilities and the lowest priority (Level 3) to unobservable inputs. Fair value measurements primarily based on observable market
	information are given a Level&nbsp;2 priority.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Debt securities are valued at quoted per share or unit market prices for which
	an official close or last trade pricing on an active exchange is available and are categorized as Level&nbsp;1 in the fair value hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Equity securities are valued at the NAV per share or unit multiplied by the number of shares or units held as of the measurement date, as reported by the fund managers. The share or unit price is quoted
	on a private market and is based on the value of the underlying investments, which are primarily based on observable inputs; such investments that are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient have not
	been classified in the fair value hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Hedge funds are stated at the NAV per share or unit (based on the estimated fair
	market value of the underlying investments) multiplied by the number of shares or units held as of the measurement date, as reported by the fund managers. These investments are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent)
	practical expedient and have not been classified in the fair value hierarchy.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The company regularly reviews fund performance
	directly with its investment advisor and the fund managers, and performs qualitative analysis to corroborate the reasonableness of the reported NAVs. For funds for which the company did not receive a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	NAV, the company recorded an estimate of the change in fair value for the latest period based on return estimates and other fund activity obtained from the fund managers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The columns labeled &#147;Investments Measured at NAV&#148; in the following tables are measured at fair value using the NAV per share (or its equivalent) practical expedient and have not been categorized
	in the fair value hierarchy. The fair value amounts presented in these tables are intended to permit a reconciliation of the fair value hierarchy to the VEBA plan assets.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following is a summary, by asset category, of the fair value and the level within the fair value hierarchy of the VEBA plan assets as of 2016 year end:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TD NOWRAP>
<FONT STYLE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="9%">
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 13: Stock-based Compensation and Other Stock Plans
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The 2011 Incentive Stock and Awards Plan (the &#147;2011 Plan&#148;) provides for the grant of stock options, performance awards, stock
	appreciation rights (&#147;SARs&#148;) and restricted stock awards (which may be designated as &#147;restricted stock units&#148; or &#147;RSUs&#148;). No further grants are being made under its predecessor, the 2001 Incentive Stock and Awards Plan
	(the &#147;2001 Plan&#148;), although outstanding awards under the 2001 Plan will continue until exercised, vested, forfeited or expired. As of 2016 year end, the 2011 Plan had 4,121,252 shares available for future grants. The company uses treasury
	stock to deliver shares under both the 2001 and 2011 Plans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Net stock-based compensation expense was $31.0&nbsp;million in
	2016, $39.8&nbsp;million in 2015 and $38.1&nbsp;million in 2014. Cash received from stock purchase and option plan exercises was $41.8&nbsp;million in 2016, $41.6&nbsp;million in 2015 and $33.0&nbsp;million in 2014. The tax benefit realized from
	both the exercise and vesting of share-based payment arrangements was $24.8&nbsp;million in 2016, $26.4&nbsp;million in 2015 and $22.3&nbsp;million in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Stock Options
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Stock options are granted with an exercise price equal to
	the market value of a share of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock on the date of grant and have a contractual term of ten years. Stock option grants vest ratably on the first, second and third anniversaries of the
	date of grant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value of each stock option award is estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes valuation
	model. The company uses historical data regarding stock option exercise and forfeiture behaviors for different participating groups to estimate the period of time that options granted are expected to be outstanding. Expected volatility is based on
	the historical volatility of the company&#146;s stock for the length of time corresponding to the expected term of the option. The expected dividend yield is based on the company&#146;s historical dividend payments. The risk-free interest rate is
	based on the U.S. treasury yield curve on the grant date for the expected term of the option.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following weighted-average
	assumptions were used in calculating the fair value of stock options granted during 2016, 2015 and 2014, using the Black-Scholes valuation model:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</FONT>
</P>

</FONT>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	76.51&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5.3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	168.3&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000;WIDTH:21%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Weighted-average
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The weighted-average grant date fair value of options granted was $22.99 in 2016, $25.64 in 2015 and $20.19 in 2014. The intrinsic value of options exercised was $35.2&nbsp;million in 2016,
	$37.6&nbsp;million in 2015 and $24.6&nbsp;million in 2014. The fair value of stock options vested was $12.7&nbsp;million in 2016, $9.9&nbsp;million in 2015 and $9.6&nbsp;million in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of 2016 year end, there was $16.6&nbsp;million of unrecognized compensation cost related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-vested
</FONT>
	stock options that is expected to be recognized as a charge to earnings over a weighted-average period of 1.5 years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Performance Awards
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Performance awards, which are granted as performance
	share units and performance-based RSUs, are earned and expensed using the fair value of the award over a contractual term of three years based on the company&#146;s performance. Vesting of the performance awards is dependent upon performance
	relative to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-defined
</FONT>
	goals for revenue growth and return on net assets for the applicable performance period. For performance achieved above specified levels, the recipient may earn additional shares of
	stock, not to exceed 100% of the number of performance awards initially granted.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The performance share units have a
	three-year performance period based on the results of the consolidated financial metrics of the company. The performance-based RSUs have a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-year
</FONT>
	performance period based on the results of the consolidated
	financial metrics of the company followed by a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	two-year
</FONT>
	cliff vesting schedule, assuming continued employment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value of performance awards is calculated using the market value of a share of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock on the date of grant and assumed forfeitures
	based on recent historical experience; in recent years, forfeitures have not been significant. The weighted-average grant date fair value of performance awards granted during 2016, 2015 and 2014 was $138.83, $139.30 and $102.11, respectively. Vested
	performance share units totaled 61,149 shares as of 2016 year end, 94,186 shares as of 2015 year end and 130,764 shares as of 2014 year end. Performance share units related to 94,186 shares, 130,764 shares and 146,313 shares were paid out in 2016,
	2015 and 2014, respectively. Earned performance share units are generally paid out following the conclusion of the applicable performance period upon approval by the Organization and Executive Compensation Committee of the company&#146;s Board of
	Directors (the &#147;Board&#148;).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Based on the company&#146;s 2016 performance, 45,502 RSUs granted in 2016 were earned;
	assuming continued employment, these RSUs will vest at the end of fiscal 2018. Based on the company&#146;s 2015 performance, 64,327 RSUs granted in 2015 were earned; assuming continued employment, these RSUs will vest at the end of fiscal 2017.
	Based on the company&#146;s 2014 performance, 78,585 RSUs granted in 2014 were earned; these RSUs vested as of fiscal 2016 year end and were paid out shortly thereafter.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Stock Appreciation Rights (&#147;SARs&#148;)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The company also issues stock-settled and cash-settled SARs to certain key
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-U.S.
</FONT>
	employees.
	SARs have a contractual term of ten years and vest ratably on the first, second and third anniversaries of the date of grant. SARs are granted with an exercise price equal to the market value of a share of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock on the date of grant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Stock-settled SARs are accounted
	for as equity instruments and provide for the issuance of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	common stock equal to the amount by which the company&#146;s stock has appreciated over the exercise price. Stock-settled SARs have an effect
	on dilutive shares and shares outstanding as any appreciation of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock value over the exercise price will be settled in shares of common stock. Cash-settled SARs provide for the cash
	payment of the excess of the fair market value of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock price on the date of exercise over the grant price. Cash-settled SARs have no effect on dilutive shares or shares outstanding as
	any appreciation of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock over the grant price is paid in cash and not in common stock.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The fair value of stock-settled SARs is estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes valuation model. The fair value of cash-settled SARs is revalued
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(mark-to-market)
</FONT>
</FONT>
	each reporting period using the Black-Scholes valuation model based on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	period-end
</FONT>
	stock price.
	The company uses historical data regarding SARs exercise and forfeiture behaviors for different participating groups to estimate the expected term of the SARs granted based on the period of time that similar instruments granted are expected to be
	outstanding. Expected volatility is based on the historical volatility of the company&#146;s stock for the length of time corresponding to the expected term of the SARs. The expected dividend yield is based on the company&#146;s historical dividend
	payments. The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. treasury yield curve in effect as of the grant date (for stock-settled SARs) or reporting date (for cash-settled SARs) for the length of time corresponding to the expected term of the SARs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following weighted-average assumptions were used in calculating the fair value of stock-settled SARs granted during 2016,
	2015 and 2014, using the Black-Scholes valuation model:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:8PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000;WIDTH:21%">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	*
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<P ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
	Weighted-average
</FONT>
</P>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The weighted-average grant date fair value of stock-settled SARs granted was $19.47 in 2016, $25.37 in 2015 and $19.55 in 2014. The intrinsic value of stock-settled SARs exercised was $1.9&nbsp;million in
	2016, $1.0&nbsp;million in 2015 and $0.1&nbsp;million in 2014. The fair value of stock-settled SARs vested was $2.1&nbsp;million in 2016, $1.4&nbsp;million in 2015 and $0.6&nbsp;million in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	As of 2016 year end there was $2.4&nbsp;million of unrecognized compensation cost related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-vested
</FONT>
	stock-settled SARs that is expected to be recognized as a charge to earnings over a weighted-average period of 1.5 years.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following weighted-average assumptions were used in calculating the fair value of cash-settled SARs granted during 2016, 2015 and 2014, using the Black-Scholes valuation model:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

	The intrinsic value of cash-settled SARs exercised was $3.3&nbsp;million in 2016, $11.0&nbsp;million in
	2015 and $5.5&nbsp;million in 2014. The fair value of cash-settled SARs vested during 2016, 2015 and 2014 was $0.2&nbsp;million, $4.6&nbsp;million and $5.9&nbsp;million, respectively.

	As of 2016 year end there was $0.3&nbsp;million of unrecognized compensation cost related to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-vested
</FONT>
	cash-settled SARs that is expected to be recognized as a
	charge to earnings over a weighted-average period of 1.5 years.

<A NAME="eolPage103"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Restricted Stock Awards &#150;
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-employee
</FONT>
	Directors
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The company awarded 7,145 shares, 8,640 shares and 10,398 shares of restricted stock to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	directors in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. The fair value of the restricted stock awards is expensed over a one year vesting period based on the fair value on the date of grant.&nbsp;All
	restrictions for the restricted stock generally lapse upon the earlier of the first anniversary of the grant date, the recipient&#146;s death or disability or in the event of a change in control, as defined in the 2011 Plan.&nbsp;If termination of
	the recipient&#146;s service occurs prior to the first anniversary of the grant date for any reason other than death or disability, the shares of restricted stock would be forfeited, unless otherwise determined by the Board.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Directors&#146; Fee Plan
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Under the Directors&#146; 1993 Fee Plan, as amended,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-employee
</FONT>
	directors may elect to receive
	up to 100% of their fees and retainer in shares of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	common stock. Directors may elect to defer receipt of all or part of these shares. For 2016, 2015 and 2014, issuances under the Directors&#146;
	Fee Plan totaled 2,579 shares, 2,747 shares and 21,533 shares, respectively, of which 2,019 shares, 1,969 shares and 20,483 shares, respectively, were deferred. As of 2016 year end, shares reserved for issuance to directors under this plan totaled
	158,105 shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Employee Stock Purchase Plan
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Substantially all
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	employees in the United States and Canada are eligible to participate in an employee stock purchase plan. The purchase price of the
	company&#146;s common stock to participants is the lesser of the mean of the high and low price of the stock on the beginning date (May 15) or ending date (the following May 14) of each plan year. For 2016, 2015 and 2014, issuances under this plan
	totaled 27,156 shares, 57,324 shares and 56,582 shares, respectively. As of 2016 year end, shares reserved for issuance under this plan totaled 780,563 shares and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	held participant contributions of
	approximately $2.4&nbsp;million. Participants are able to withdraw from the plan at any time prior to the ending date and receive back all contributions made during the plan year. Compensation expense for plan participants was zero in 2016,
	$2.3&nbsp;million in 2015 and $1.5&nbsp;million in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<I>
	Franchisee Stock Purchase Plan
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	All franchisees in the United States and Canada are eligible to participate in a franchisee stock purchase plan.&nbsp;The purchase price
	of the company&#146;s common stock to participants is the lesser of the mean of the high and low price of the stock on the beginning date (May 15) or ending date (the following May 14) of each plan year. For 2016, 2015 and 2014, issuances under this
	plan totaled 42,867 shares, 74,001 shares and 74,502 shares, respectively. As of 2016 year end, shares reserved for issuance under this plan totaled 613,469 shares and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	held participant contributions of
	approximately $4.6&nbsp;million. Participants are able to withdraw from the plan at any time prior to the ending date and receive back all contributions made during the plan year. The company recognized a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	benefit of $0.2&nbsp;million in 2016;
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-to-market
</FONT>
</FONT>
	expense for plan participants was $2.9&nbsp;million in 2015
	and $1.7&nbsp;million in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 14: Capital Stock
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has undertaken repurchases of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	common stock from time to time to offset dilution created by shares issued for
	employee and franchisee stock purchase plans, stock awards and other corporate purposes.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	repurchased 758,000 shares, 723,000 shares and 680,000 shares in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively. As of 2016
	year end,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has remaining availability to repurchase up to an additional $207.2
<B>
</B>
	&nbsp;million in common stock pursuant to Board authorizations. The purchase of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	common stock is at the company&#146;s discretion, subject to prevailing financial and market conditions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Cash dividends paid in 2016, 2015 and 2014 totaled $147.5&nbsp;million, $127.9&nbsp;million and $107.6&nbsp;million, respectively. Cash dividends per share in 2016, 2015 and 2014 were $2.54, $2.20 and
	$1.85, respectively. On February&nbsp;9, 2017, the company&#146;s Board declared a quarterly dividend of $0.71 per share, payable on March&nbsp;10, 2017, to shareholders of record on February&nbsp;24, 2017.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	leases facilities, office equipment and vehicles under
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cancelable
</FONT>
	operating and capital leases that extend for varying amounts of time.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>

<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	sub-lease
</FONT>
	rental income, are as follows:

<TD>
	&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Rent expense for worldwide facilities, office equipment and vehicles, net of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	sub-lease
</FONT>
	rental income, was $31.2&nbsp;million, $29.4&nbsp;million and $30.6&nbsp;million in 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	provides product warranties for specific product lines and accrues for estimated future warranty cost in the period in which the sale is recorded.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	calculates its accrual requirements based on historic warranty loss experience that is periodically adjusted for recent actual experience, including the timing of claims during the warranty period and actual
	costs incurred.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	product warranty accrual activity for 2016, 2015 and 2014 is as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Approximately 2,800 employees, or 23% of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	worldwide
	workforce, are represented by unions and/or covered under collective bargaining agreements. The number of covered union employees whose contracts expire over the next five years approximates 2,100 employees in 2017, 500 employees in 2018, and 200
	employees in 2019; there are no contracts currently scheduled to expire in 2020 or 2021. In recent years,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	has not experienced any significant work slowdowns, stoppages or other labor disruptions.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	is involved in various legal matters that are being litigated and/or settled
	in the ordinary course of business. Although it is not possible to predict the outcome of these legal matters, management believes that the results of these legal matters will not have a material impact on
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="CENTER">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="31%">
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="TOP">

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 18: Segments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	business segments are based on the organization structure used by management for making operating and investment decisions and for assessing
	performance.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	reportable business segments are: (i)&nbsp;the Commercial&nbsp;&amp; Industrial Group; (ii)&nbsp;the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Tools Group; (iii)&nbsp;the
	Repair Systems&nbsp;&amp; Information Group; and (iv)&nbsp;Financial Services. The Commercial&nbsp;&amp; Industrial Group consists of business operations serving a broad range of industrial and commercial customers worldwide, including customers in
	the aerospace, natural resources, government, power generation, transportation and technical education market segments (collectively, &#147;critical industries&#148;), primarily through direct and distributor channels. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Tools Group consists of business operations primarily serving vehicle service and repair technicians through the company&#146;s worldwide mobile tool distribution channel. The Repair Systems&nbsp;&amp;
	Information Group consists of business operations serving other professional vehicle repair customers worldwide, primarily owners and managers of independent repair shops and original equipment manufacturer (&#147;OEM&#148;) dealership service and
	repair shops (&#147;OEM dealerships&#148;), through direct and distributor channels. Financial Services consists of the business operations of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	finance subsidiaries.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	evaluates the performance of its operating segments based on segment revenues, including
	both external and intersegment net sales, and segment operating earnings.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	accounts for intersegment sales and transfers based primarily on standard costs with reasonable
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	mark-ups
</FONT>
	established between the segments. Identifiable assets by segment are those assets used in the respective reportable segment&#146;s operations. Corporate assets consist of cash and cash equivalents
	(excluding cash held at Financial Services), deferred income taxes and certain other assets. All significant intersegment amounts are eliminated to arrive at
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	consolidated financial results.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Neither
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	nor any of its segments depend on any single customer, small group of
	customers or government for more than 10% of its revenues.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D308837D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="1">
<I>
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (continued)
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Products and Services:
</B>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	derives
	net sales from a broad line of products and complementary services that are grouped into three categories: (i)&nbsp;tools; (ii) diagnostics and repair information; and (iii)&nbsp;equipment. The tools product category includes
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on&#146;s
</FONT>
	hand tools, power tools and tool storage products. The diagnostics and repair information product category includes handheld and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	PC-based
</FONT>
	diagnostic products,
	service and repair information products, diagnostic software solutions, electronic parts catalogs, and business management systems and services to help owners and managers of independent repair shops and OEM dealerships manage and track performance.
	The equipment product category includes solutions for the diagnosis and service of vehicles and industrial equipment. Through its financial services businesses,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	also derives revenue from various
	financing programs designed to facilitate the sales of its products and support its franchise business. Further product line information is not presented as it is not practicable to do so.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	The following table shows the consolidated net sales and revenues of these product groups in the last three years:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Note 20: Subsequent Event
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On January&nbsp;17, 2017,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	repaid the 2017 Notes upon maturity with an aggregate of $150&nbsp;million of available cash and cash generated from issuances of
	commercial paper.
</FONT>

<A NAME="D308837DEX23_HTM_TX308837_25">

	CONSENT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	We consent to the incorporation by reference in Registration Statement

	Nos.&nbsp;33-37924,

</FONT>
	and

	333-208479

	on Form

	S-8
</FONT>
	of our reports dated February&nbsp;9,
	2017, relating to the consolidated financial statements of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Incorporated and the effectiveness of

	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Incorporated&#146;s internal control over financial

	Snap-on

	Incorporated for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.

<TD WIDTH="35%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="32%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="1%">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">

<DIV CLASS="eolNewPage"></DIV>
<A NAME="eolPage120"></A>
<A NAME="D308837DEX311_HTM"></A>
<EFX_EXHIBIT_31>
<A NAME="FIS_EXHIBIT_31"></A>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="RIGHT">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	EXHIBIT 31.1
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
<A NAME="D308837DEX311_HTM_TX308837_26">
</A>
	Certification of the Chief Executive Officer pursuant to
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="CENTER">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
<B>
	Section&nbsp;302 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	On October&nbsp;31, 2016,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Incorporated (the &#147;registrant&#148;) acquired
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	Holding AB
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	(&#147;Car-O-Liner&#148;).
</FONT>
</FONT>
	Management has excluded this
	acquisition from its assessment of internal control over financial reporting for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Car-O-Liner
</FONT>
</FONT>
	represented less than 4% of the
	registrant&#146;s total assets at December&nbsp;31, 2016, and less than 1% of the registrant&#146;s 2016 net sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	I, Nicholas T. Pinchuk,
	certify that:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	1. I have reviewed this annual report on Form
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-K
</FONT>
	of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Snap-on
</FONT>
	Incorporated;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	2. Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any
	untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	3. Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present
	in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	4. The registrant&#146;s other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	13a-15(e)
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15d-15(e))
</FONT>
	and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	13a-15(f)
</FONT>
	and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	15d-15(f))
</FONT>
	for the registrant and have:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	a) Designed such disclosure controls
	and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within
	those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	b) Designed such
	internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
	financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	c)
	Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this
	report based on such evaluation; and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	d) Disclosed in this report any change in the registrant&#146;s internal
	control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant&#146;s most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant&#146;s fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially
	affect, the registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting; and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	5. The registrant&#146;s other certifying
	officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant&#146;s auditors and the audit committee of the registrant&#146;s board of directors (or persons performing the
	equivalent functions):
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	a) All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of
	internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrant&#146;s ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX; MARGIN-LEFT:4%" ALIGN="JUSTIFY">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the
	registrant&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	Date: February&nbsp;9, 2017
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX">
	&nbsp;
</P>

</TD>
</TR>

<TD VALIGN="TOP" STYLE="BORDER-BOTTOM:1PX SOLID #000000">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">
	/s/ Nicholas T. Pinchuk
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT SIZE="1">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</TD>

</TD>

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" SIZE="2">

</FONT>

<A NAME="FIS_EXHIBIT_31_2"></A>
<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">

<P STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:1PX;MARGIN-TOP:0PX;MARGIN-BOTTOM:2PX;BORDER-BOTTOM:0.5PT SOLID #000000">
